verses.13:2: And Judith was left along in the tent, and Holofernes lying along upon his bed: for he was filled with wine.
verses.13:3: Now Judith had commanded her maid to stand without her bedchamber, and to wait for her. coming forth, as she did daily: for she said she would go forth to her prayers, and she spake to Bagoas according to the same purpose.
verses.13:4: So all went forth and none was left in the bedchamber, neither little nor great. Then Judith, standing by his bed, said in her heart, O Lord God of all power, look at this present upon the works of mine hands for the exaltation of Jerusalem.
verses.13:5: For now is the time to help thine inheritance, and to execute thine enterprizes to the destruction of the enemies which are risen against us.
verses.13:6: Then she came to the pillar of the bed, which was at Holofernes’ head, and took down his fauchion from thence,
verses.13:7: And approached to his bed, and took hold of the hair of his head, and said, Strengthen me, O Lord God of Israel, this day.
verses.13:8: And she smote twice upon his neck with all her might, and she took away his head from him.
verses.13:9: And tumbled his body down from the bed, and pulled down the canopy from the pillars; and anon after she went forth, and gave Holofernes his head to her maid;
verses.13:10: And she put it in her bag of meat: so they twain went together according to their custom unto prayer: and when they passed the camp, they compassed the valley, and went up the mountain of Bethulia, and came to the gates thereof.
verses.13:11: Then said Judith afar off, to the watchmen at the gate, Open, open now the gate: God, even our God, is with us, to shew his power yet in Jerusalem, and his forces against the enemy, as he hath even done this day.
verses.13:12: Now when the men of her city heard her voice, they made haste to go down to the gate of their city, and they called the elders of the city.
verses.13:13: And then they ran all together, both small and great, for it was strange unto them that she was come: so they opened the gate, and received them, and made a fire for a light, and stood round about them.
verses.13:14: Then she said to them with a loud voice, Praise, praise God, praise God, I say, for he hath not taken away his mercy from the house of Israel, but hath destroyed our enemies by mine hands this night.
verses.13:15: So she took the head out of the bag, and shewed it, and said unto them, behold the head of Holofernes, the chief captain of the army of Assur, and behold the canopy, wherein he did lie in his drunkenness; and the Lord hath smitten him by the hand of a woman.
verses.13:16: As the Lord liveth, who hath kept me in my way that I went, my countenance hath deceived him to his destruction, and yet hath he not committed sin with me, to defile and shame me.
verses.13:17: Then all the people were wonderfully astonished, and bowed themselves and worshipped God, and said with one accord, Blessed be thou, O our God, which hast this day brought to nought the enemies of thy people.
verses.13:18: Then said Ozias unto her, O daughter, blessed art thou of the most high God above all the women upon the earth; and blessed be the Lord God, which hath created the heavens and the earth, which hath directed thee to the cutting off of the head of the chief of our enemies.
verses.13:19: For this thy confidence shall not depart from the heart of men, which remember the power of God for ever.
verses.13:20: And God turn these things to thee for a perpetual praise, to visit thee in good things because thou hast not spared thy life for the affliction of our nation, but hast revenged our ruin, walking a straight way before our God. And all the people said; So be it, so be it.
verses.14:1: Then said Judith unto them, Hear me now, my brethren, and take this head, and hang it upon the highest place of your walls.
verses.14:2: And so soon as the morning shall appear, and the sun shall come forth upon the earth, take ye every one his weapons, and go forth every valiant man out of the city, and set ye a captain over them, as though ye would go down into the field toward the watch of the Assyrians; but go not down.
verses.14:3: Then they shall take their armour, and shall go into their camp, and raise up the captains of the army of Assur, and shall run to the tent of Holofernes, but shall not find him: then fear shall fall upon them, and they shall flee before your face.
verses.14:4: So ye, and all that inhabit the coast of Israel, shall pursue them, and overthrow them as they go.
verses.14:5: But before ye do these things, call me Achior the Ammonite, that he may see and know him that despised the house of Israel, and that sent him to us as it were to his death.
verses.14:6: Then they called Achior out of the house of Ozias; and when he was come, and saw the head of Holofernes in a man’s hand in the assembly of the people, he fell down on his face, and his spirit failed.
verses.14:7: But when they had recovered him, he fell at Judith’s feet, and reverenced her, and said, Blessed art thou in all the tabernacles of Juda, and in all nations, which hearing thy name shall be astonished.
verses.14:8: Now therefore tell me all the things that thou hast done in these days. Then Judith declared unto him in the midst of the people all that she had done, from the day that she went forth until that hour she spake unto them.
verses.14:9: And when she had left off speaking, the people shouted with a loud voice, and made a joyful noise in their city.
verses.14:10: And when Achior had seen all that the God of Israel had done, he believed in God greatly, and circumcised the flesh of his foreskin, and was joined unto the house of Israel unto this day.
verses.14:11: And as soon as the morning arose, they hanged the head of Holofernes upon the wall, and every man took his weapons, and they went forth by bands unto the straits of the mountain.
verses.14:12: But when the Assyrians saw them, they sent to their leaders, which came to their captains and tribunes, and to every one of their rulers.
verses.14:13: So they came to Holofernes’ tent, and said to him that had the charge of all his things, Waken now our lord: for the slaves have been bold to come down against us to battle, that they may be utterly destroyed.
verses.14:14: Then went in Bagoas, and knocked at the door of the tent; for he thought that he had slept with Judith.
verses.14:15: But because none answered, he opened it, and went into the bedchamber, and found him cast upon the floor dead, and his head was taken from him.
verses.14:16: Therefore he cried with a loud voice, with weeping, and sighing, and a mighty cry, and rent his garments.
verses.14:17: After he went into the tent where Judith lodged: and when he found her not, he leaped out to the people, and cried,
verses.14:18: These slaves have dealt treacherously; one woman of the Hebrews hath brought shame upon the house of king Nabuchodonosor: for, behold, Holofernes lieth upon the ground without a head.
verses.14:19: When the captains of the Assyrians’ army heard these words, they rent their coats and their minds were wonderfully troubled, and there was a cry and a very great noise throughout the camp.
verses.15:1: And when they that were in the tents heard, they were astonished at the thing that was done.
verses.15:2: And fear and trembling fell upon them, so that there was no man that durst abide in the sight of his neighbour, but rushing out all together, they fled into every way of the plain, and of the hill country.
verses.15:3: They also that had camped in the mountains round about Bethulia fled away. Then the children of Israel, every one that was a warrior among them, rushed out upon them.
verses.15:4: Then sent Ozias to Betomasthem, and to Bebai, and Chobai, and Cola and to all the coasts of Israel, such as should tell the things that were done, and that all should rush forth upon their enemies to destroy them.
verses.15:5: Now when the children of Israel heard it, they all fell upon them with one consent, and slew them unto Chobai: likewise also they that came from Jerusalem, and from all the hill country, (for men had told them what things were done in the camp of their enemies) and they that were in Galaad, and in Galilee, chased them with a great slaughter, until they were past Damascus and the borders thereof.
verses.15:6: And the residue that dwelt at Bethulia, fell upon the camp of Assur, and spoiled them, and were greatly enriched.
verses.15:7: And the children of Israel that returned from the slaughter had that which remained; and the villages and the cities, that were in the mountains and in the plain, gat many spoils: for the multitude was very great.
verses.15:8: Then Joacim the high priest, and the ancients of the children of Israel that dwelt in Jerusalem, came to behold the good things that God had shewed to Israel, and to see Judith, and to salute her.
verses.15:9: And when they came unto her, they blessed her with one accord, and said unto her, Thou art the exaltation of Jerusalem, thou art the great glory of Israel, thou art the great rejoicing of our nation:
verses.15:10: Thou hast done all these things by thine hand: thou hast done much good to Israel, and God is pleased therewith: blessed be thou of the Almighty Lord for evermore. And all the people said, So be it.
verses.15:11: And the people spoiled the camp the space of thirty days: and they gave unto Judith Holofernes his tent, and all his plate, and beds, and vessels, and all his stuff: and she took it and laid it on her mule; and made ready her carts, and laid them thereon.
verses.15:12: Then all the women of Israel ran together to see her, and blessed her, and made a dance among them for her: and she took branches in her hand, and gave also to the women that were with her.
verses.15:13: And they put a garland of olive upon her and her maid that was with her, and she went before all the people in the dance, leading all the women: and all the men of Israel followed in their armour with garlands, and with songs in their mouths.
verses.16:1: Then Judith began to sing this thanksgiving in all Israel, and all the people sang after her this song of praise.
verses.16:2: And Judith said, Begin unto my God with timbrels, sing unto my Lord with cymbals: tune unto him a new psalm: exalt him, and call upon his name.
verses.16:3: For God breaketh the battles: for among the camps in the midst of the people he hath delivered me out of the hands of them that persecuted me.
verses.16:4: Assur came out of the mountains from the north, he came with ten thousands of his army, the multitude whereof stopped the torrents, and their horsemen have covered the hills.
verses.16:5: He bragged that he would burn up my borders, and kill my young men with the sword, and dash the sucking children against the ground, and make mine infants as a prey, and my virgins as a spoil.
verses.16:6: But the Almighty Lord hath disappointed them by the hand of a woman.
verses.16:7: For the mighty one did not fall by the young men, neither did the sons of the Titans smite him, nor high giants set upon him: but Judith the daughter of Merari weakened him with the beauty of her countenance.
verses.16:8: For she put off the garment of her widowhood for the exaltation of those that were oppressed in Israel, and anointed her face with ointment, and bound her hair in a tire, and took a linen garment to deceive him.
verses.16:9: Her sandals ravished his eyes, her beauty took his mind prisoner, and the fauchion passed through his neck.
verses.16:10: The Persians quaked at her boldness, and the Medes were daunted at her hardiness.
verses.16:11: Then my afflicted shouted for joy, and my weak ones cried aloud; but they were astonished: these lifted up their voices, but they were overthrown.
verses.16:12: The sons of the damsels have pierced them through, and wounded them as fugatives’ children: they perished by the battle of the Lord.
verses.16:13: I will sing unto the Lord a new song: O Lord, thou art great and glorious, wonderful in strength, and invincible.
verses.16:14: Let all creatures serve thee: for thou spakest, and they were made, thou didst send forth thy spirit, and it created them, and there is none that can resist thy voice.
verses.16:15: For the mountains shall be moved from their foundations with the waters, the rocks shall melt as wax at thy presence: yet thou art merciful to them that fear thee.
verses.16:16: For all sacrifice is too little for a sweet savour unto thee, and all the fat is not sufficient for thy burnt offering: but he that feareth the Lord is great at all times.
verses.16:17: Woe to the nations that rise up against my kindred! the Lord Almighty will take vengeance of them in the day of judgment, in putting fire and worms in their flesh; and they shall feel them, and weep for ever.
verses.16:18: Now as soon as they entered into Jerusalem, they worshipped the Lord; and as soon as the people were purified, they offered their burnt offerings, and their free offerings, and their gifts.
verses.16:19: Judith also dedicated all the stuff of Holofernes, which the people had given her, and gave the canopy, which she had taken out of his bedchamber, for a gift unto the Lord.
verses.16:20: So the people continued feasting in Jerusalem before the sanctuary for the space of three months and Judith remained with them.
verses.16:21: After this time every one returned to his own inheritance, and Judith went to Bethulia, and remained in her own possession, and was in her time honourable in all the country.
verses.16:22: And many desired her, but none knew her all the days of her life, after that Manasses her husband was dead, and was gathered to his people.
verses.16:23: But she increased more and more in honour, and waxed old in her husband’s house, being an hundred and five years old, and made her maid free; so she died in Bethulia: and they buried her in the cave of her husband Manasses.
verses.16:24: And the house of Israel lamented her seven days: and before she died, she did distribute her goods to all them that were nearest of kindred to Manasses her husband, and to them that were the nearest of her kindred.
verses.16:25: And there was none that made the children of Israel any more afraid in the days of Judith, nor a long time after her death.

verses.1:1: And these are the words of the book, which Baruch the son of Nerias, the son of Maasias, the son of Sedecias, the son of Asadias, the son of Chelcias, wrote in Babylon,
verses.1:2: In the fifth year, and in the seventh day of the month, what time as the Chaldeans took Jerusalem, and burnt it with fire.
verses.1:3: And Baruch did read the words of this book in the hearing of Jechonias the son of Joachim king of Juda, and in the ears of all the people that came to hear the book,
verses.1:4: And in the hearing of the nobles, and of the king’s sons, and in the hearing of the elders, and of all the people, from the lowest unto the highest, even of all them that dwelt at Babylon by the river Sud.
verses.1:5: Whereupon they wept, fasted, and prayed before the Lord.
verses.1:6: They made also a collection of money according to every man’s power:
verses.1:7: And they sent it to Jerusalem unto Joachim the high priest, the son of Chelcias, son of Salom, and to the priests, and to all the people which were found with him at Jerusalem,
verses.1:8: At the same time when he received the vessels of the house of the Lord, that were carried out of the temple, to return them into the land of Juda, the tenth day of the month Sivan, namely, silver vessels, which Sedecias the son of Josias king of Jada had made,
verses.1:9: After that Nabuchodonosor king of Babylon had carried away Jechonias, and the princes, and the captives, and the mighty men, and the people of the land, from Jerusalem, and brought them unto Babylon.
verses.1:10: And they said, Behold, we have sent you money to buy you burnt offerings, and sin offerings, and incense, and prepare ye manna, and offer upon the altar of the Lord our God;
verses.1:11: And pray for the life of Nabuchodonosor king of Babylon, and for the life of Balthasar his son, that their days may be upon earth as the days of heaven:
verses.1:12: And the Lord will give us strength, and lighten our eyes, and we shall live under the shadow of Nabuchodonosor king of Babylon, and under the shadow of Balthasar his son, and we shall serve them many days, and find favour in their sight.
verses.1:13: Pray for us also unto the Lord our God, for we have sinned against the Lord our God; and unto this day the fury of the Lord and his wrath is not turned from us.
verses.1:14: And ye shall read this book which we have sent unto you, to make confession in the house of the Lord, upon the feasts and solemn days.
verses.1:15: And ye shall say, To the Lord our God belongeth righteousness, but unto us the confusion of faces, as it is come to pass this day, unto them of Juda, and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem,
verses.1:16: And to our kings, and to our princes, and to our priests, and to our prophets, and to our fathers:
verses.1:17: For we have sinned before the Lord,
verses.1:18: And disobeyed him, and have not hearkened unto the voice of the Lord our God, to walk in the commandments that he gave us openly:
verses.1:19: Since the day that the Lord brought our forefathers out of the land of Egypt, unto this present day, we have been disobedient unto the Lord our God, and we have been negligent in not hearing his voice.
verses.1:20: Wherefore the evils cleaved unto us, and the curse, which the Lord appointed by Moses his servant at the time that he brought our fathers out of the land of Egypt, to give us a land that floweth with milk and honey, like as it is to see this day.
verses.1:21: Nevertheless we have not hearkened unto the voice of the Lord our God, according unto all the words of the prophets, whom he sent unto us:
verses.1:22: But every man followed the imagination of his own wicked heart, to serve strange gods, and to do evil in the sight of the Lord our God.
verses.2:1: Therefore the Lord hath made good his word, which he pronounced against us, and against our judges that judged Israel, and against our kings, and against our princes, and against the men of Israel and Juda,
verses.2:2: To bring upon us great plagues, such as never happened under the whole heaven, as it came to pass in Jerusalem, according to the things that were written in the law of Moses;
verses.2:3: That a man should eat the flesh of his own son, and the flesh of his own daughter.
verses.2:4: Moreover he hath delivered them to be in subjection to all the kingdoms that are round about us, to be as a reproach and desolation among all the people round about, where the Lord hath scattered them.
verses.2:5: Thus we were cast down, and not exalted, because we have sinned against the Lord our God, and have not been obedient unto his voice.
verses.2:6: To the Lord our God appertaineth righteousness: but unto us and to our fathers open shame, as appeareth this day.
verses.2:7: For all these plagues are come upon us, which the Lord hath pronounced against us
verses.2:8: Yet have we not prayed before the Lord, that we might turn every one from the imaginations of his wicked heart.
verses.2:9: Wherefore the Lord watched over us for evil, and the Lord hath brought it upon us: for the Lord is righteous in all his works which he hath commanded us.
verses.2:10: Yet we have not hearkened unto his voice, to walk in the commandments of the Lord, that he hath set before us.
verses.2:11: And now, O Lord God of Israel, that hast brought thy people out of the land of Egypt with a mighty hand, and high arm, and with signs, and with wonders, and with great power, and hast gotten thyself a name, as appeareth this day:
verses.2:12: O Lord our God, we have sinned, we have done ungodly, we have dealt unrighteously in all thine ordinances.
verses.2:13: Let thy wrath turn from us: for we are but a few left among the heathen, where thou hast scattered us.
verses.2:14: Hear our prayers, O Lord, and our petitions, and deliver us for thine own sake, and give us favour in the sight of them which have led us away:
verses.2:15: That all the earth may know that thou art the Lord our God, because Israel and his posterity is called by thy name.
verses.2:16: O Lord, look down from thine holy house, and consider us: bow down thine ear, O Lord, to hear us.
verses.2:17: Open thine eyes, and behold; for the dead that are in the graves, whose souls are taken from their bodies, will give unto the Lord neither praise nor righteousness:
verses.2:18: But the soul that is greatly vexed, which goeth stooping and feeble, and the eyes that fail, and the hungry soul, will give thee praise and righteousness, O Lord.
verses.2:19: Therefore we do not make our humble supplication before thee, O Lord our God, for the righteousness of our fathers, and of our kings.
verses.2:20: For thou hast sent out thy wrath and indignation upon us, as thou hast spoken by thy servants the prophets, saying,
verses.2:21: Thus saith the Lord, Bow down your shoulders to serve the king of Babylon: so shall ye remain in the land that I gave unto your fathers.
verses.2:22: But if ye will not hear the voice of the Lord, to serve the king of Babylon,
verses.2:23: I will cause to cease out of the cites of Judah, and from without Jerusalem, the voice of mirth, and the voice of joy, the voice of the bridegroom, and the voice of the bride: and the whole land shall be desolate of inhabitants.
verses.2:24: But we would not hearken unto thy voice, to serve the king of Babylon: therefore hast thou made good the words that thou spakest by thy servants the prophets, namely, that the bones of our kings, and the bones of our fathers, should be taken out of their place.
verses.2:25: And, lo, they are cast out to the heat of the day, and to the frost of the night, and they died in great miseries by famine, by sword, and by pestilence.
verses.2:26: And the house which is called by thy name hast thou laid waste, as it is to be seen this day, for the wickedness of the house of Israel and the house of Juda.
verses.2:27: O Lord our God, thou hast dealt with us after all thy goodness, and according to all that great mercy of thine,
verses.2:28: As thou spakest by thy servant Moses in the day when thou didst command him to write the law before the children of Israel, saying,
verses.2:29: If ye will not hear my voice, surely this very great multitude shall be turned into a small number among the nations, where I will scatter them.
verses.2:30: For I knew that they would not hear me, because it is a stiffnecked people: but in the land of their captivities they shall remember themselves.
verses.2:31: And shall know that I am the Lord their God: for I will give them an heart, and ears to hear:
verses.2:32: And they shall praise me in the land of their captivity, and think upon my name,
verses.2:33: And return from their stiff neck, and from their wicked deeds: for they shall remember the way of their fathers, which sinned before the Lord.
verses.2:34: And I will bring them again into the land which I promised with an oath unto their fathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and they shall be lords of it: and I will increase them, and they shall not be diminished.
verses.2:35: And I will make an everlasting covenant with them to be their God, and they shall be my people: and I will no more drive my people of Israel out of the land that I have given them.
verses.3:1: O Lord Almighty, God of Israel, the soul in anguish the troubled spirit, crieth unto thee.
verses.3:2: Hear, O Lord, and have mercy; ar thou art merciful: and have pity upon us, because we have sinned before thee.
verses.3:3: For thou endurest for ever, and we perish utterly.
verses.3:4: O Lord Almighty, thou God of Israel, hear now the prayers of the dead Israelites, and of their children, which have sinned before thee, and not hearkened unto the voice of thee their God: for the which cause these plagues cleave unto us.
verses.3:5: Remember not the iniquities of our forefathers: but think upon thy power and thy name now at this time.
verses.3:6: For thou art the Lord our God, and thee, O Lord, will we praise.
verses.3:7: And for this cause thou hast put thy fear in our hearts, to the intent that we should call upon thy name, and praise thee in our captivity: for we have called to mind all the iniquity of our forefathers, that sinned before thee.
verses.3:8: Behold, we are yet this day in our captivity, where thou hast scattered us, for a reproach and a curse, and to be subject to payments, according to all the iniquities of our fathers, which departed from the Lord our God.
verses.3:9: Hear, Israel, the commandments of life: give ear to understand wisdom.
verses.3:10: How happeneth it Israel, that thou art in thine enemies’ land, that thou art waxen old in a strange country, that thou art defiled with the dead,
verses.3:11: That thou art counted with them that go down into the grave?
verses.3:12: Thou hast forsaken the fountain of wisdom.
verses.3:13: For if thou hadst walked in the way of God, thou shouldest have dwelled in peace for ever.
verses.3:14: Learn where is wisdom, where is strength, where is understanding; that thou mayest know also where is length of days, and life, where is the light of the eyes, and peace.
verses.3:15: Who hath found out her place? or who hath come into her treasures ?
verses.3:16: Where are the princes of the heathen become, and such as ruled the beasts upon the earth;
verses.3:17: They that had their pastime with the fowls of the air, and they that hoarded up silver and gold, wherein men trust, and made no end of their getting?
verses.3:18: For they that wrought in silver, and were so careful, and whose works are unsearchable,
verses.3:19: They are vanished and gone down to the grave, and others are come up in their steads.
verses.3:20: Young men have seen light, and dwelt upon the earth: but the way of knowledge have they not known,
verses.3:21: Nor understood the paths thereof, nor laid hold of it: their children were far off from that way.
verses.3:22: It hath not been heard of in Chanaan, neither hath it been seen in Theman.
verses.3:23: The Agarenes that seek wisdom upon earth, the merchants of Meran and of Theman, the authors of fables, and searchers out of understanding; none of these have known the way of wisdom, or remember her paths.
verses.3:24: O Israel, how great is the house of God! and how large is the place of his possession!
verses.3:25: Great, and hath none end; high, and unmeasurable.
verses.3:26: There were the giants famous from the beginning, that were of so great stature, and so expert in war.
verses.3:27: Those did not the Lord choose, neither gave he the way of knowledge unto them:
verses.3:28: But they were destroyed, because they had no wisdom, and perished through their own foolishness.
verses.3:29: Who hath gone up into heaven, and taken her, and brought her down from the clouds?
verses.3:30: Who hath gone over the sea, and found her, and will bring her for pure gold?
verses.3:31: No man knoweth her way, nor thinketh of her path.
verses.3:32: But he that knoweth all things knoweth her, and hath found her out with his understanding: he that prepared the earth for evermore hath filled it with fourfooted beasts:
verses.3:33: He that sendeth forth light, and it goeth, calleth it again, and it obeyeth him with fear.
verses.3:34: The stars shined in their watches, and rejoiced: when he calleth them, they say, Here we be; and so with cheerfulness they shewed light unto him that made them.
verses.3:35: This is our God, and there shall none other be accounted of in comparison of him
verses.3:36: He hath found out all the way of knowledge, and hath given it unto Jacob his servant, and to Israel his beloved.
verses.3:37: Afterward did he shew himself upon earth, and conversed with men.
verses.4:1: This is the book of the commandments of God, and the law that endureth for ever: all they that keep it shall come to life; but such as leave it shall die.
verses.4:2: Turn thee, O Jacob, and take hold of it: walk in the presence of the light thereof, that thou mayest be illuminated.
verses.4:3: Give not thine honour to another, nor the things that are profitable unto thee to a strange nation.
verses.4:4: O Israel, happy are we: for things that are pleasing to God are made known unto us.
verses.4:5: Be of good cheer, my people, the memorial of Israel.
verses.4:6: Ye were sold to the nations, not for your destruction: but because ye moved God to wrath, ye were delivered unto the enemies.
verses.4:7: For ye provoked him that made you by sacrificing unto devils, and not to God.
verses.4:8: Ye have forgotten the everlasting God, that brought you up; and ye have grieved Jerusalem, that nursed you.
verses.4:9: For when she saw the wrath of God coming upon you, she said, Hearken, O ye that dwell about Sion: God hath brought upon me great mourning;
verses.4:10: For I saw the captivity of my sons and daughters, which the Everlasting brought upon them.
verses.4:11: With joy did I nourish them; but sent them away with weeping and mourning.
verses.4:12: Let no man rejoice over me, a widow, and forsaken of many, who for the sins of my children am left desolate; because they departed from the law of God.
verses.4:13: They knew not his statutes, nor walked in the ways of his commandments, nor trod in the paths of discipline in his righteousness.
verses.4:14: Let them that dwell about Sion come, and remember ye the captivity of my sons and daughters, which the Everlasting hath brought upon them.
verses.4:15: For he hath brought a nation upon them from far, a shameless nation, and of a strange language, who neither reverenced old man, nor pitied child.
verses.4:16: These have carried away the dear beloved children of the widow, and left her that was alone desolate without daughters.
verses.4:17: But what can I help you?
verses.4:18: For he that brought these plagues upon you will deliver you from the hands of your enemies.
verses.4:19: Go your way, O my children, go your way: for I am left desolate.
verses.4:20: I have put off the clothing of peace, and put upon me the sackcloth of my prayer: I will cry unto the Everlasting in my days.
verses.4:21: Be of good cheer, O my children, cry unto the Lord, and he will deliver you from the power and hand of the enemies.
verses.4:22: For my hope is in the Everlasting, that he will save you; and joy is come unto me from the Holy One, because of the mercy which shall soon come unto you from the Everlasting our Saviour.
verses.4:23: For I sent you out with mourning and weeping: but God will give you to me again with joy and gladness for ever.
verses.4:24: Like as now the neighbours of Sion have seen your captivity: so shall they see shortly your salvation from our God which shall come upon you with great glory, and brightness of the Everlasting.
verses.4:25: My children, suffer patiently the wrath that is come upon you from God: for thine enemy hath persecuted thee; but shortly thou shalt see his destruction, and shalt tread upon his neck.
verses.4:26: My delicate ones have gone rough ways, and were taken away as a flock caught of the enemies.
verses.4:27: Be of good comfort, O my children, and cry unto God: for ye shall be remembered of him that brought these things upon you.
verses.4:28: For as it was your mind to go astray from God: so, being returned, seek him ten times more.
verses.4:29: For he that hath brought these plagues upon you shall bring you everlasting joy with your salvation.
verses.4:30: Take a good heart, O Jerusalem: for he that gave thee that name will comfort thee.
verses.4:31: Miserable are they that afflicted thee, and rejoiced at thy fall.
verses.4:32: Miserable are the cities which thy children served: miserable is she that received thy sons.
verses.4:33: For as she rejoiced at thy ruin, and was glad of thy fall: so shall she be grieved for her own desolation.
verses.4:34: For I will take away the rejoicing of her great multitude, and her pride shall be turned into mourning.
verses.4:35: For fire shall come upon her from the Everlasting, long to endure; and she shall be inhabited of devils for a great time.
verses.4:36: O Jerusalem, look about thee toward the east, and behold the joy that cometh unto thee from God.
verses.4:37: Lo, thy sons come, whom thou sentest away, they come gathered together from the east to the west by the word of the Holy One, rejoicing in the glory of God.
verses.5:1: Put off, O Jerusalem, the garment of mourning and affliction, and put on the comeliness of the glory that cometh from God for ever.
verses.5:2: Cast about thee a double garment of the righteousness which cometh from God; and set a diadem on thine head of the glory of the Everlasting.
verses.5:3: For God will shew thy brightness unto every country under heaven.
verses.5:4: For thy name shall be called of God for ever The peace of righteousness, and The glory of God’s worship.
verses.5:5: Arise, O Jerusalem, and stand on high, and look about toward the east, and behold thy children gathered from the west unto the east by the word of the Holy One, rejoicing in the remembrance of God.
verses.5:6: For they departed from thee on foot, and were led away of their enemies: but God bringeth them unto thee exalted with glory, as children of the kingdom.
verses.5:7: For God hath appointed that every high hill, and banks of long continuance, should be cast down, and valleys filled up, to make even the ground, that Israel may go safely in the glory of God,
verses.5:8: Moreover even the woods and every sweetsmelling tree shall overshadow Israel by the commandment of God.
verses.5:9: For God shall lead Israel with joy in the light of his glory with the mercy and righteousness that cometh from him.

verses.1:1: And it happened, after that Alexander son of Philip, the Macedonian, who came out of the land of Chettiim, had smitten Darius king of the Persians and Medes, that he reigned in his stead, the first over Greece,
verses.1:2: And made many wars, and won many strong holds, and slew the kings of the earth,
verses.1:3: And went through to the ends of the earth, and took spoils of many nations, insomuch that the earth was quiet before him; whereupon he was exalted and his heart was lifted up.
verses.1:4: And he gathered a mighty strong host and ruled over countries, and nations, and kings, who became tributaries unto him.
verses.1:5: And after these things he fell sick, and perceived that he should die.
verses.1:6: Wherefore he called his servants, such as were honourable, and had been brought up with him from his youth, and parted his kingdom among them, while he was yet alive.
verses.1:7: So Alexander reigned twelves years, and then died.
verses.1:8: And his servants bare rule every one in his place.
verses.1:9: And after his death they all put crowns upon themselves; so did their sons after them many years: and evils were multiplied in the earth.
verses.1:10: And there came out of them a wicked root Antiochus surnamed Epiphanes, son of Antiochus the king, who had been an hostage at Rome, and he reigned in the hundred and thirty and seventh year of the kingdom of the Greeks.
verses.1:11: In those days went there out of Israel wicked men, who persuaded many, saying, Let us go and make a covenant with the heathen that are round about us: for since we departed from them we have had much sorrow.
verses.1:12: So this device pleased them well.
verses.1:13: Then certain of the people were so forward herein, that they went to the king, who gave them licence to do after the ordinances of the heathen:
verses.1:14: Whereupon they built a place of exercise at Jerusalem according to the customs of the heathen:
verses.1:15: And made themselves uncircumcised, and forsook the holy covenant, and joined themselves to the heathen, and were sold to do mischief.
verses.1:16: Now when the kingdom was established before Antiochus, he thought to reign over Egypt that he might have the dominion of two realms.
verses.1:17: Wherefore he entered into Egypt with a great multitude, with chariots, and elephants, and horsemen, and a great navy,
verses.1:18: And made war against Ptolemee king of Egypt: but Ptolemee was afraid of him, and fled; and many were wounded to death.
verses.1:19: Thus they got the strong cities in the land of Egypt and he took the spoils thereof.
verses.1:20: And after that Antiochus had smitten Egypt, he returned again in the hundred forty and third year, and went up against Israel and Jerusalem with a great multitude,
verses.1:21: And entered proudly into the sanctuary, and took away the golden altar, and the candlestick of light, and all the vessels thereof,
verses.1:22: And the table of the shewbread, and the pouring vessels, and the vials. and the censers of gold, and the veil, and the crown, and the golden ornaments that were before the temple, all which he pulled off.
verses.1:23: He took also the silver and the gold, and the precious vessels: also he took the hidden treasures which he found.
verses.1:24: And when he had taken all away, he went into his own land, having made a great massacre, and spoken very proudly.
verses.1:25: Therefore there was a great mourning in Israel, in every place where they were;
verses.1:26: So that the princes and elders mourned, the virgins and young men were made feeble, and the beauty of women was changed.
verses.1:27: Every bridegroom took up lamentation, and she that sat in the marriage chamber was in heaviness,
verses.1:28: The land also was moved for the inhabitants thereof, and all the house of Jacob was covered with confusion.
verses.1:29: And after two years fully expired the king sent his chief collector of tribute unto the cities of Juda, who came unto Jerusalem with a great multitude,
verses.1:30: And spake peaceable words unto them, but all was deceit: for when they had given him credence, he fell suddenly upon the city, and smote it very sore, and destroyed much people of Israel.
verses.1:31: And when he had taken the spoils of the city, he set it on fire, and pulled down the houses and walls thereof on every side.
verses.1:32: But the women and children took they captive, and possessed the cattle.
verses.1:33: Then builded they the city of David with a great and strong wall, and with mighty towers, and made it a strong hold for them.
verses.1:34: And they put therein a sinful nation, wicked men, and fortified themselves therein.
verses.1:35: They stored it also with armour and victuals, and when they had gathered together the spoils of Jerusalem, they laid them up there, and so they became a sore snare:
verses.1:36: For it was a place to lie in wait against the sanctuary, and an evil adversary to Israel.
verses.1:37: Thus they shed innocent blood on every side of the sanctuary, and defiled it:
verses.1:38: Insomuch that the inhabitants of Jerusalem fled because of them: whereupon the city was made an habitation of strangers, and became strange to those that were born in her; and her own children left her.
verses.1:39: Her sanctuary was laid waste like a wilderness, her feasts were turned into mourning, her sabbaths into reproach her honour into contempt.
verses.1:40: As had been her glory, so was her dishonour increased, and her excellency was turned into mourning.
verses.1:41: Moreover king Antiochus wrote to his whole kingdom, that all should be one people,
verses.1:42: And every one should leave his laws: so all the heathen agreed according to the commandment of the king.
verses.1:43: Yea, many also of the Israelites consented to his religion, and sacrificed unto idols, and profaned the sabbath.
verses.1:44: For the king had sent letters by messengers unto Jerusalem and the cities of Juda that they should follow the strange laws of the land,
verses.1:45: And forbid burnt offerings, and sacrifice, and drink offerings, in the temple; and that they should profane the sabbaths and festival days:
verses.1:46: And pollute the sanctuary and holy people:
verses.1:47: Set up altars, and groves, and chapels of idols, and sacrifice swine’s flesh, and unclean beasts:
verses.1:48: That they should also leave their children uncircumcised, and make their souls abominable with all manner of uncleanness and profanation:
verses.1:49: To the end they might forget the law, and change all the ordinances.
verses.1:50: And whosoever would not do according to the commandment of the king, he said, he should die.
verses.1:51: In the selfsame manner wrote he to his whole kingdom, and appointed overseers over all the people, commanding the cities of Juda to sacrifice, city by city.
verses.1:52: Then many of the people were gathered unto them, to wit every one that forsook the law; and so they committed evils in the land;
verses.1:53: And drove the Israelites into secret places, even wheresoever they could flee for succour.
verses.1:54: Now the fifteenth day of the month Casleu, in the hundred forty and fifth year, they set up the abomination of desolation upon the altar, and builded idol altars throughout the cities of Juda on every side;
verses.1:55: And burnt incense at the doors of their houses, and in the streets.
verses.1:56: And when they had rent in pieces the books of the law which they found, they burnt them with fire.
verses.1:57: And whosoever was found with any the book of the testament, or if any committed to the law, the king’s commandment was, that they should put him to death.
verses.1:58: Thus did they by their authority unto the Israelites every month, to as many as were found in the cities.
verses.1:59: Now the five and twentieth day of the month they did sacrifice upon the idol altar, which was upon the altar of God.
verses.1:60: At which time according to the commandment they put to death certain women, that had caused their children to be circumcised.
verses.1:61: And they hanged the infants about their necks, and rifled their houses, and slew them that had circumcised them.
verses.1:62: Howbeit many in Israel were fully resolved and confirmed in themselves not to eat any unclean thing.
verses.1:63: Wherefore the rather to die, that they might not be defiled with meats, and that they might not profane the holy covenant: so then they died.
verses.1:64: And there was very great wrath upon Israel.
verses.2:1: In those days arose Mattathias the son of John, the son of Simeon, a priest of the sons of Joarib, from Jerusalem, and dwelt in Modin.
verses.2:2: And he had five sons, Joannan, called Caddis:
verses.2:3: Simon; called Thassi:
verses.2:5: Eleazar, called Avaran: and Jonathan, whose surname was Apphus.
verses.2:6: And when he saw the blasphemies that were committed in Juda and Jerusalem,
verses.2:7: He said, Woe is me! wherefore was I born to see this misery of my people, and of the holy city, and to dwell there, when it was delivered into the hand of the enemy, and the sanctuary into the hand of strangers?
verses.2:8: Her temple is become as a man without glory.
verses.2:9: Her glorious vessels are carried away into captivity, her infants are slain in the streets, her young men with the sword of the enemy.
verses.2:10: What nation hath not had a part in her kingdom and gotten of her spoils?
verses.2:11: All her ornaments are taken away; of a free woman she is become a bondslave.
verses.2:12: And, behold, our sanctuary, even our beauty and our glory, is laid waste, and the Gentiles have profaned it.
verses.2:13: To what end therefore shall we live any longer?
verses.2:14: Then Mattathias and his sons rent their clothes, and put on sackcloth, and mourned very sore.
verses.2:15: In the mean while the king’s officers, such as compelled the people to revolt, came into the city Modin, to make them sacrifice.
verses.2:16: And when many of Israel came unto them, Mattathias also and his sons came together.
verses.2:17: Then answered the king’s officers, and said to Mattathias on this wise, Thou art a ruler, and an honourable and great man in this city, and strengthened with sons and brethren:
verses.2:18: Now therefore come thou first, and fulfil the king’s commandment, like as all the heathen have done, yea, and the men of Juda also, and such as remain at Jerusalem: so shalt thou and thy house be in the number of the king’s friends, and thou and thy children shall be honoured with silver and gold, and many rewards.
verses.2:19: Then Mattathias answered and spake with a loud voice, Though all the nations that are under the king’s dominion obey him, and fall away every one from the religion of their fathers, and give consent to his commandments:
verses.2:20: Yet will I and my sons and my brethren walk in the covenant of our fathers.
verses.2:21: God forbid that we should forsake the law and the ordinances.
verses.2:22: We will not hearken to the king’s words, to go from our religion, either on the right hand, or the left.
verses.2:23: Now when he had left speaking these words, there came one of the Jews in the sight of all to sacrifice on the altar which was at Modin, according to the king’s commandment.
verses.2:24: Which thing when Mattathias saw, he was inflamed with zeal, and his reins trembled, neither could he forbear to shew his anger according to judgment: wherefore he ran, and slew him upon the altar.
verses.2:25: Also the king’s commissioner, who compelled men to sacrifice, he killed at that time, and the altar he pulled down.
verses.2:26: Thus dealt he zealously for the law of God like as Phinees did unto Zambri the son of Salom.
verses.2:27: And Mattathias cried throughout the city with a loud voice, saying, Whosoever is zealous of the law, and maintaineth the covenant, let him follow me.
verses.2:28: So he and his sons fled into the mountains, and left all that ever they had in the city.
verses.2:29: Then many that sought after justice and judgment went down into the wilderness, to dwell there:
verses.2:30: Both they, and their children, and their wives; and their cattle; because afflictions increased sore upon them.
verses.2:31: Now when it was told the king’s servants, and the host that was at Jerusalem, in the city of David, that certain men, who had broken the king’s commandment, were gone down into the secret places in the wilderness,
verses.2:32: They pursued after them a great number, and having overtaken them, they camped against them, and made war against them on the sabbath day.
verses.2:33: And they said unto them, Let that which ye have done hitherto suffice; come forth, and do according to the commandment of the king, and ye shall live.
verses.2:34: But they said, We will not come forth, neither will we do the king’s commandment, to profane the sabbath day.
verses.2:35: So then they gave them the battle with all speed.
verses.2:36: Howbeit they answered them not, neither cast they a stone at them, nor stopped the places where they lay hid;
verses.2:37: But said, Let us die all in our innocency: heaven and earth will testify for us, that ye put us to death wrongfully.
verses.2:38: So they rose up against them in battle on the sabbath, and they slew them, with their wives and children and their cattle, to the number of a thousand people.
verses.2:39: Now when Mattathias and his friends understood hereof, they mourned for them right sore.
verses.2:40: And one of them said to another, If we all do as our brethren have done, and fight not for our lives and laws against the heathen, they will now quickly root us out of the earth.
verses.2:41: At that time therefore they decreed, saying, Whosoever shall come to make battle with us on the sabbath day, we will fight against him; neither will we die all, as our brethren that were murdered im the secret places.
verses.2:42: Then came there unto him a company of Assideans who were mighty men of Israel, even all such as were voluntarily devoted unto the law.
verses.2:43: Also all they that fled for persecution joined themselves unto them, and were a stay unto them.
verses.2:44: So they joined their forces, and smote sinful men in their anger, and wicked men in their wrath: but the rest fled to the heathen for succour.
verses.2:45: Then Mattathias and his friends went round about, and pulled down the altars:
verses.2:46: And what children soever they found within the coast of Israel uncircumcised, those they circumcised valiantly.
verses.2:47: They pursued also after the proud men, and the work prospered in their hand.
verses.2:48: So they recovered the law out of the hand of the Gentiles, and out of the hand of kings, neither suffered they the sinner to triumph.
verses.2:49: Now when the time drew near that Mattathias should die, he said unto his sons, Now hath pride and rebuke gotten strength, and the time of destruction, and the wrath of indignation:
verses.2:50: Now therefore, my sons, be ye zealous for the law, and give your lives for the covenant of your fathers.
verses.2:51: Call to remembrance what acts our fathers did in their time; so shall ye receive great honour and an everlasting name.
verses.2:52: Was not Abraham found faithful in temptation, and it was imputed unto him for righteousness?
verses.2:53: Joseph in the time of his distress kept the commandment and was made lord of Egypt.
verses.2:54: Phinees our father in being zealous and fervent obtained the covenant of an everlasting priesthood.
verses.2:55: Jesus for fulfilling the word was made a judge in Israel.
verses.2:56: Caleb for bearing witness before the congregation received the heritage of the land.
verses.2:57: David for being merciful possessed the throne of an everlasting kingdom.
verses.2:58: Elias for being zealous and fervent for the law was taken up into heaven.
verses.2:59: Ananias, Azarias, and Misael, by believing were saved out of the flame.
verses.2:60: Daniel for his innocency was delivered from the mouth of lions.
verses.2:61: And thus consider ye throughout all ages, that none that put their trust in him shall be overcome.
verses.2:62: Fear not then the words of a sinful man: for his glory shall be dung and worms.
verses.2:63: To day he shall be lifted up and to morrow he shall not be found, because he is returned into his dust, and his thought is come to nothing.
verses.2:64: Wherefore, ye my sons, be valiant and shew yourselves men in the behalf of the law; for by it shall ye obtain glory.
verses.2:65: And behold, I know that your brother Simon is a man of counsel, give ear unto him alway: he shall be a father unto you.
verses.2:66: As for Judas Maccabeus, he hath been mighty and strong, even from his youth up: let him be your captain, and fight the battle of the people.
verses.2:67: Take also unto you all those that observe the law, and avenge ye the wrong of your people.
verses.2:68: Recompense fully the heathen, and take heed to the commandments of the law.
verses.2:69: So he blessed them, and was gathered to his fathers.
verses.2:70: And he died in the hundred forty and sixth year, and his sons buried him in the sepulchres of his fathers at Modin, and all Israel made great lamentation for him.
verses.3:1: Then his son Judas, called Maccabeus, rose up in his stead.
verses.3:2: And all his brethren helped him, and so did all they that held with his father, and they fought with cheerfulness the battle of Israel.
verses.3:3: So he gat his people great honour, and put on a breastplate as a giant, and girt his warlike harness about him, and he made battles, protecting the host with his sword.
verses.3:4: In his acts he was like a lion, and like a lion’s whelp roaring for his prey.
verses.3:5: For He pursued the wicked, and sought them out, and burnt up those that vexed his people.
verses.3:6: Wherefore the wicked shrunk for fear of him, and all the workers of iniquity were troubled, because salvation prospered in his hand.
verses.3:7: He grieved also many kings, and made Jacob glad with his acts, and his memorial is blessed for ever.
verses.3:8: Moreover he went through the cities of Juda, destroying the ungodly out of them, and turning away wrath from Israel:
verses.3:9: So that he was renowned unto the utmost part of the earth, and he received unto him such as were ready to perish.
verses.3:10: Then Apollonius gathered the Gentiles together, and a great host out of Samaria, to fight against Israel.
verses.3:11: Which thing when Judas perceived, he went forth to meet him, and so he smote him, and slew him: many also fell down slain, but the rest fled.
verses.3:12: Wherefore Judas took their spoils, and Apollonius’ sword also, and therewith he fought all his life long.
verses.3:13: Now when Seron, a prince of the army of Syria, heard say that Judas had gathered unto him a multitude and company of the faithful to go out with him to war;
verses.3:14: He said, I will get me a name and honour in the kingdom; for I will go fight with Judas and them that are with him, who despise the king’s commandment.
verses.3:15: So he made him ready to go up, and there went with him a mighty host of the ungodly to help him, and to be avenged of the children of Israel.
verses.3:16: And when he came near to the going up of Bethhoron, Judas went forth to meet him with a small company:
verses.3:17: Who, when they saw the host coming to meet them, said unto Judas, How shall we be able, being so few, to fight against so great a multitude and so strong, seeing we are ready to faint with fasting all this day?
verses.3:18: Unto whom Judas answered, It is no hard matter for many to be shut up in the hands of a few; and with the God of heaven it is all one, to deliver with a great multitude, or a small company:
verses.3:19: For the victory of battle standeth not in the multitude of an host; but strength cometh from heaven.
verses.3:20: They come against us in much pride and iniquity to destroy us, and our wives and children, and to spoil us:
verses.3:21: But we fight for our lives and our laws.
verses.3:22: Wherefore the Lord himself will overthrow them before our face: and as for you, be ye not afraid of them.
verses.3:23: Now as soon as he had left off speaking, he leapt suddenly upon them, and so Seron and his host was overthrown before him.
verses.3:24: And they pursued them from the going down of Bethhoron unto the plain, where were slain about eight hundred men of them; and the residue fled into the land of the Philistines.
verses.3:25: Then began the fear of Judas and his brethren, and an exceeding great dread, to fall upon the nations round about them:
verses.3:26: Insomuch as his fame came unto the king, and all nations talked of the battles of Judas.
verses.3:27: Now when king Antiochus heard these things, he was full of indignation: wherefore he sent and gathered together all the forces of his realm, even a very strong army.
verses.3:28: He opened also his treasure, and gave his soldiers pay for a year, commanding them to be ready whensoever he should need them.
verses.3:29: Nevertheless, when he saw that the money of his treasures failed and that the tributes in the country were small, because of the dissension and plague, which he had brought upon the land in taking away the laws which had been of old time;
verses.3:30: He feared that he should not be able to bear the charges any longer, nor to have such gifts to give so liberally as he did before: for he had abounded above the kings that were before him.
verses.3:31: Wherefore, being greatly perplexed in his mind, he determined to go into Persia, there to take the tributes of the countries, and to gather much money.
verses.3:32: So he left Lysias, a nobleman, and one of the blood royal, to oversee the affairs of the king from the river Euphrates unto the borders of Egypt:
verses.3:33: And to bring up his son Antiochus, until he came again.
verses.3:34: Moreover he delivered unto him the half of his forces, and the elephants, and gave him charge of all things that he would have done, as also concerning them that dwelt in Juda and Jerusalem:
verses.3:35: To wit, that he should send an army against them, to destroy and root out the strength of Israel, and the remnant of Jerusalem, and to take away their memorial from that place;
verses.3:36: And that he should place strangers in all their quarters, and divide their land by lot.
verses.3:37: So the king took the half of the forces that remained, and departed from Antioch, his royal city, the hundred forty and seventh year; and having passed the river Euphrates, he went through the high countries.
verses.3:38: Then Lysias chose Ptolemee the son of Dorymenes, Nicanor, and Gorgias, mighty men of the king’s friends:
verses.3:39: And with them he sent forty thousand footmen, and seven thousand horsemen, to go into the land of Juda, and to destroy it, as the king commanded.
verses.3:40: So they went forth with all their power, and came and pitched by Emmaus in the plain country.
verses.3:41: And the merchants of the country, hearing the fame of them, took silver and gold very much, with servants, and came into the camp to buy the children of Israel for slaves: a power also of Syria and of the land of the Philistines joined themselves unto them.
verses.3:42: Now when Judas and his brethren saw that miseries were multiplied, and that the forces did encamp themselves in their borders: for they knew how the king had given commandment to destroy the people, and utterly abolish them;
verses.3:43: They said one to another, Let us restore the decayed fortune of our people, and let us fight for our people and the sanctuary.
verses.3:44: Then was the congregation gathered together, that they might be ready for battle, and that they might pray, and ask mercy and compassion.
verses.3:45: Now Jerusalem lay void as a wilderness, there was none of her children that went in or out: the sanctuary also was trodden down, and aliens kept the strong hold; the heathen had their habitation in that place; and joy was taken from Jacob, and the pipe with the harp ceased.
verses.3:46: Wherefore the Israelites assembled themselves together, and came to Maspha, over against Jerusalem; for in Maspha was the place where they prayed aforetime in Israel.
verses.3:47: Then they fasted that day, and put on sackcloth, and cast ashes upon their heads, and rent their clothes,
verses.3:48: And laid open the book of the law, wherein the heathen had sought to paint the likeness of their images.
verses.3:49: They brought also the priests’ garments, and the firstfruits, and the tithes: and the Nazarites they stirred up, who had accomplished their days.
verses.3:50: Then cried they with a loud voice toward heaven, saying, What shall we do with these, and whither shall we carry them away?
verses.3:51: For thy sanctuary is trodden down and profaned, and thy priests are in heaviness, and brought low.
verses.3:52: And lo, the heathen are assembled together against us to destroy us: what things they imagine against us, thou knowest.
verses.3:53: How shall we be able to stand against them, except thou, O God, be our help?
verses.3:54: Then sounded they with trumpets, and cried with a loud voice.
verses.3:55: And after this Judas ordained captains over the people, even captains over thousands, and over hundreds, and over fifties, and over tens.
verses.3:56: But as for such as were building houses, or had betrothed wives, or were planting vineyards, or were fearful, those he commanded that they should return, every man to his own house, according to the law.
verses.3:57: So the camp removed, and pitched upon the south side of Emmaus.
verses.3:58: And Judas said, arm yourselves, and be valiant men, and see that ye be in readiness against the morning, that ye may fight with these nations, that are assembled together against us to destroy us and our sanctuary:
verses.3:59: For it is better for us to die in battle, than to behold the calamities of our people and our sanctuary.
verses.3:60: Nevertheless, as the will of God is in heaven, so let him do.
verses.4:1: Then took Gorgias five thousand footmen, and a thousand of the best horsemen, and removed out of the camp by night;
verses.4:2: To the end he might rush in upon the camp of the Jews, and smite them suddenly. And the men of the fortress were his guides.
verses.4:3: Now when Judas heard thereof he himself removed, and the valiant men with him, that he might smite the king’s army which was at Emmaus,
verses.4:4: While as yet the forces were dispersed from the camp.
verses.4:5: In the mean season came Gorgias by night into the camp of Judas: and when he found no man there, he sought them in the mountains: for said he, These fellows flee from us
verses.4:6: But as soon as it was day, Judas shewed himself in the plain with three thousand men, who nevertheless had neither armour nor swords to their minds.
verses.4:7: And they saw the camp of the heathen, that it was strong and well harnessed, and compassed round about with horsemen; and these were expert of war.
verses.4:8: Then said Judas to the men that were with him, Fear ye not their multitude, neither be ye afraid of their assault.
verses.4:9: Remember how our fathers were delivered in the Red sea, when Pharaoh pursued them with an army.
verses.4:10: Now therefore let us cry unto heaven, if peradventure the Lord will have mercy upon us, and remember the covenant of our fathers, and destroy this host before our face this day:
verses.4:11: That so all the heathen may know that there is one who delivereth and saveth Israel.
verses.4:12: Then the strangers lifted up their eyes, and saw them coming over against them.
verses.4:13: Wherefore they went out of the camp to battle; but they that were with Judas sounded their trumpets.
verses.4:14: So they joined battle, and the heathen being discomfited fled into the plain.
verses.4:15: Howbeit all the hindmost of them were slain with the sword: for they pursued them unto Gazera, and unto the plains of Idumea, and Azotus, and Jamnia, so that there were slain of them upon a three thousand men.
verses.4:16: This done, Judas returned again with his host from pursuing them,
verses.4:17: And said to the people, Be not greedy of the spoil inasmuch as there is a battle before us,
verses.4:18: And Gorgias and his host are here by us in the mountain: but stand ye now against our enemies, and overcome them, and after this ye may boldly take the spoils.
verses.4:19: As Judas was yet speaking these words, there appeared a part of them looking out of the mountain:
verses.4:20: Who when they perceived that the Jews had put their host to flight and were burning the tents; for the smoke that was seen declared what was done:
verses.4:21: When therefore they perceived these things, they were sore afraid, and seeing also the host of Judas in the plain ready to fight,
verses.4:22: They fled every one into the land of strangers.
verses.4:23: Then Judas returned to spoil the tents, where they got much gold, and silver, and blue silk, and purple of the sea, and great riches.
verses.4:24: After this they went home, and sung a song of thanksgiving, and praised the Lord in heaven: because it is good, because his mercy endureth forever.
verses.4:25: Thus Israel had a great deliverance that day.
verses.4:26: Now all the strangers that had escaped came and told Lysias what had happened:
verses.4:27: Who, when he heard thereof, was confounded and discouraged, because neither such things as he would were done unto Israel, nor such things as the king commanded him were come to pass.
verses.4:28: The next year therefore following Lysias gathered together threescore thousand choice men of foot, and five thousand horsemen, that he might subdue them.
verses.4:29: So they came into Idumea, and pitched their tents at Bethsura, and Judas met them with ten thousand men.
verses.4:30: And when he saw that mighty army, he prayed and said, Blessed art thou, O Saviour of Israel, who didst quell the violence of the mighty man by the hand of thy servant David, and gavest the host of strangers into the hands of Jonathan the son of Saul, and his armourbearer;
verses.4:31: Shut up this army in the hand of thy people Israel, and let them be confounded in their power and horsemen:
verses.4:32: Make them to be of no courage, and cause the boldness of their strength to fall away, and let them quake at their destruction:
verses.4:33: Cast them down with the sword of them that love thee, and let all those that know thy name praise thee with thanksgiving.
verses.4:34: So they joined battle; and there were slain of the host of Lysias about five thousand men, even before them were they slain.
verses.4:35: Now when Lysias saw his army put to flight, and the manliness of Judas’ soldiers, and how they were ready either to live or die valiantly, he went into Antiochia, and gathered together a company of strangers, and having made his army greater than it was, he purposed to come again into Judea.
verses.4:36: Then said Judas and his brethren, Behold, our enemies are discomfited: let us go up to cleanse and dedicate the sanctuary.
verses.4:37: Upon this all the host assembled themselves together, and went up into mount Sion.
verses.4:38: And when they saw the sanctuary desolate, and the altar profaned, and the gates burned up, and shrubs growing in the courts as in a forest, or in one of the mountains, yea, and the priests’ chambers pulled down;
verses.4:39: They rent their clothes, and made great lamentation, and cast ashes upon their heads,
verses.4:40: And fell down flat to the ground upon their faces, and blew an alarm with the trumpets, and cried toward heaven.
verses.4:41: Then Judas appointed certain men to fight against those that were in the fortress, until he had cleansed the sanctuary.
verses.4:42: So he chose priests of blameless conversation, such as had pleasure in the law:
verses.4:43: Who cleansed the sanctuary, and bare out the defiled stones into an unclean place.
verses.4:44: And when as they consulted what to do with the altar of burnt offerings, which was profaned;
verses.4:45: They thought it best to pull it down, lest it should be a reproach to them, because the heathen had defiled it: wherefore they pulled it down,
verses.4:46: And laid up the stones in the mountain of the temple in a convenient place, until there should come a prophet to shew what should be done with them.
verses.4:47: Then they took whole stones according to the law, and built a new altar according to the former;
verses.4:48: And made up the sanctuary, and the things that were within the temple, and hallowed the courts.
verses.4:49: They made also new holy vessels, and into the temple they brought the candlestick, and the altar of burnt offerings, and of incense, and the table.
verses.4:50: And upon the altar they burned incense, and the lamps that were upon the candlestick they lighted, that they might give light in the temple.
verses.4:51: Furthermore they set the loaves upon the table, and spread out the veils, and finished all the works which they had begun to make.
verses.4:52: Now on the five and twentieth day of the ninth month, which is called the month Casleu, in the hundred forty and eighth year, they rose up betimes in the morning,
verses.4:53: And offered sacrifice according to the law upon the new altar of burnt offerings, which they had made.
verses.4:54: Look, at what time and what day the heathen had profaned it, even in that was it dedicated with songs, and citherns, and harps, and cymbals.
verses.4:55: Then all the people fell upon their faces, worshipping and praising the God of heaven, who had given them good success.
verses.4:56: And so they kept the dedication of the altar eight days and offered burnt offerings with gladness, and sacrificed the sacrifice of deliverance and praise.
verses.4:57: They decked also the forefront of the temple with crowns of gold, and with shields; and the gates and the chambers they renewed, and hanged doors upon them.
verses.4:58: Thus was there very great gladness among the people, for that the reproach of the heathen was put away.
verses.4:59: Moreover Judas and his brethren with the whole congregation of Israel ordained, that the days of the dedication of the altar should be kept in their season from year to year by the space of eight days, from the five and twentieth day of the month Casleu, with mirth and gladness.
verses.4:60: At that time also they builded up the mount Sion with high walls and strong towers round about, lest the Gentiles should come and tread it down as they had done before.
verses.4:61: And they set there a garrison to keep it, and fortified Bethsura to preserve it; that the people might have a defence against Idumea.
verses.5:1: Now when the nations round about heard that the altar was built and the sanctuary renewed as before, it displeased them very much.
verses.5:2: Wherefore they thought to destroy the generation of Jacob that was among them, and thereupon they began to slay and destroy the people.
verses.5:3: Then Judas fought against the children of Esau in Idumea at Arabattine, because they besieged Gael: and he gave them a great overthrow, and abated their courage, and took their spoils.
verses.5:4: Also he remembered the injury of the children of Bean, who had been a snare and an offence unto the people, in that they lay in wait for them in the ways.
verses.5:5: He shut them up therefore in the towers, and encamped against them, and destroyed them utterly, and burned the towers of that place with fire, and all that were therein.
verses.5:6: Afterward he passed over to the children of Ammon, where he found a mighty power, and much people, with Timotheus their captain.
verses.5:7: So he fought many battles with them, till at length they were discomfited before him; and he smote them.
verses.5:8: And when he had taken Jazar, with the towns belonging thereto, he returned into Judea.
verses.5:9: Then the heathen that were at Galaad assembled themselves together against the Israelites that were in their quarters, to destroy them; but they fled to the fortress of Dathema.
verses.5:10: And sent letters unto Judas and his brethren, The heathen that are round about us are assembled together against us to destroy us:
verses.5:11: And they are preparing to come and take the fortress whereunto we are fled, Timotheus being captain of their host.
verses.5:12: Come now therefore, and deliver us from their hands, for many of us are slain:
verses.5:13: Yea, all our brethren that were in the places of Tobie are put to death: their wives and their children also they have carried away captives, and borne away their stuff; and they have destroyed there about a thousand men.
verses.5:14: While these letters were yet reading, behold, there came other messengers from Galilee with their clothes rent, who reported on this wise,
verses.5:15: And said, They of Ptolemais, and of Tyrus, and Sidon, and all Galilee of the Gentiles, are assembled together against us to consume us.
verses.5:16: Now when Judas and the people heard these words, there assembled a great congregation together, to consult what they should do for their brethren, that were in trouble, and assaulted of them.
verses.5:17: Then said Judas unto Simon his brother, Choose thee out men, and go and deliver thy brethren that are in Galilee, for I and Jonathan my brother will go into the country of Galaad.
verses.5:18: So he left Joseph the son of Zacharias, and Azarias, captains of the people, with the remnant of the host in Judea to keep it.
verses.5:19: Unto whom he gave commandment, saying, Take ye the charge of this people, and see that ye make not war against the heathen until the time that we come again.
verses.5:20: Now unto Simon were given three thousand men to go into Galilee, and unto Judas eight thousand men for the country of Galaad.
verses.5:21: Then went Simon into Galilee, where he fought many battles with the heathen, so that the heathen were discomfited by him.
verses.5:22: And he pursued them unto the gate of Ptolemais; and there were slain of the heathen about three thousand men, whose spoils he took.
verses.5:23: And those that were in Galilee, and in Arbattis, with their wives and their children, and all that they had, took he away with him, and brought them into Judea with great joy.
verses.5:24: Judas Maccabeus also and his brother Jonathan went over Jordan, and travelled three days’ journey in the wilderness,
verses.5:25: Where they met with the Nabathites, who came unto them in a peaceable manner, and told them every thing that had happened to their brethren in the land of Galaad:
verses.5:26: And how that many of them were shut up in Bosora, and Bosor, and Alema, Casphor, Maked, and Carnaim; all these cities are strong and great:
verses.5:27: And that they were shut up in the rest of the cities of the country of Galaad, and that against to morrow they had appointed to bring their host against the forts, and to take them, and to destroy them all in one day.
verses.5:28: Hereupon Judas and his host turned suddenly by the way of the wilderness unto Bosora; and when he had won the city, he slew all the males with the edge of the sword, and took all their spoils, and burned the city with fire,
verses.5:29: From whence he removed by night, and went till he came to the fortress.
verses.5:30: And betimes in the morning they looked up, and, behold, there was an innumerable people bearing ladders and other engines of war, to take the fortress: for they assaulted them.
verses.5:31: When Judas therefore saw that the battle was begun, and that the cry of the city went up to heaven, with trumpets, and a great sound,
verses.5:32: He said unto his host, Fight this day for your brethren.
verses.5:33: So he went forth behind them in three companies, who sounded their trumpets, and cried with prayer.
verses.5:34: Then the host of Timotheus, knowing that it was Maccabeus, fled from him: wherefore he smote them with a great slaughter; so that there were killed of them that day about eight thousand men.
verses.5:35: This done, Judas turned aside to Maspha; and after he had assaulted it he took and slew all the males therein, and received the spoils thereof and and burnt it with fire.
verses.5:36: From thence went he, and took Casphon, Maged, Bosor, and the other cities of the country of Galaad.
verses.5:37: After these things gathered Timotheus another host and encamped against Raphon beyond the brook.
verses.5:38: So Judas sent men to espy the host, who brought him word, saying, All the heathen that be round about us are assembled unto them, even a very great host.
verses.5:39: He hath also hired the Arabians to help them and they have pitched their tents beyond the brook, ready to come and fight against thee. Upon this Judas went to meet them.
verses.5:40: Then Timotheus said unto the captains of his host, When Judas and his host come near the brook, if he pass over first unto us, we shall not be able to withstand him; for he will mightily prevail against us:
verses.5:41: But if he be afraid, and camp beyond the river, we shall go over unto him, and prevail against him.
verses.5:42: Now when Judas came near the brook, he caused the scribes of the people to remain by the brook: unto whom he gave commandment, saying, Suffer no man to remain in the camp, but let all come to the battle.
verses.5:43: So he went first over unto them, and all the people after him: then all the heathen, being discomfited before him, cast away their weapons, and fled unto the temple that was at Carnaim.
verses.5:44: But they took the city, and burned the temple with all that were therein. Thus was Carnaim subdued, neither could they stand any longer before Judas.
verses.5:45: Then Judas gathered together all the Israelites that were in the country of Galaad, from the least unto the greatest, even their wives, and their children, and their stuff, a very great host, to the end they might come into the land of Judea.
verses.5:46: Now when they came unto Ephron, (this was a great city in the way as they should go, very well fortified) they could not turn from it, either on the right hand or the left, but must needs pass through the midst of it.
verses.5:47: Then they of the city shut them out, and stopped up the gates with stones.
verses.5:48: Whereupon Judas sent unto them in peaceable manner, saying, Let us pass through your land to go into our own country, and none shall do you any hurt; we will only pass through on foot: howbeit they would not open unto him.
verses.5:49: Wherefore Judas commanded a proclamation to be made throughout the host, that every man should pitch his tent in the place where he was.
verses.5:50: So the soldiers pitched, and assaulted the city all that day and all that night, till at the length the city was delivered into his hands:
verses.5:51: Who then slew all the males with the edge of the sword, and rased the city, and took the spoils thereof, and passed through the city over them that were slain.
verses.5:52: After this went they over Jordan into the great plain before Bethsan.
verses.5:53: And Judas gathered together those that came behind, and exhorted the people all the way through, till they came into the land of Judea.
verses.5:54: So they went up to mount Sion with joy and gladness, where they offered burnt offerings, because not one of them were slain until they had returned in peace.
verses.5:55: Now what time as Judas and Jonathan were in the land of Galaad, and Simon his brother in Galilee before Ptolemais,
verses.5:56: Joseph the son of Zacharias, and Azarias, captains of the garrisons, heard of the valiant acts and warlike deeds which they had done.
verses.5:57: Wherefore they said, Let us also get us a name, and go fight against the heathen that are round about us.
verses.5:58: So when they had given charge unto the garrison that was with them, they went toward Jamnia.
verses.5:59: Then came Gorgias and his men out of the city to fight against them.
verses.5:60: And so it was, that Joseph and Azaras were put to flight, and pursued unto the borders of Judea: and there were slain that day of the people of Israel about two thousand men.
verses.5:61: Thus was there a great overthrow among the children of Israel, because they were not obedient unto Judas and his brethren, but thought to do some valiant act.
verses.5:62: Moreover these men came not of the seed of those, by whose hand deliverance was given unto Israel.
verses.5:63: Howbeit the man Judas and his brethren were greatly renowned in the sight of all Israel, and of all the heathen, wheresoever their name was heard of;
verses.5:64: Insomuch as the the people assembled unto them with joyful acclamations.
verses.5:65: Afterward went Judas forth with his brethren, and fought against the children of Esau in the land toward the south, where he smote Hebron, and the towns thereof, and pulled down the fortress of it, and burned the towers thereof round about.
verses.5:66: From thence he removed to go into the land of the Philistines, and passed through Samaria.
verses.5:67: At that time certain priests, desirous to shew their valour, were slain in battle, for that they went out to fight unadvisedly.
verses.5:68: So Judas turned to Azotus in the land of the Philistines, and when he had pulled down their altars, and burned their carved images with fire, and spoiled their cities, he returned into the land of Judea.
verses.6:1: About that time king Antiochus travelling through the high countries heard say, that Elymais in the country of Persia was a city greatly renowned for riches, silver, and gold;
verses.6:2: And that there was in it a very rich temple, wherein were coverings of gold, and breastplates, and shields, which Alexander, son of Philip, the Macedonian king, who reigned first among the Grecians, had left there.
verses.6:3: Wherefore he came and sought to take the city, and to spoil it; but he was not able, because they of the city, having had warning thereof,
