verses.77:18: And it came to pass on the one and twentieth day in the eighth month that I, Baruch, came and sat down under the oak under the shadow of the branches, and no man was with me, but I was alone.
verses.77:19: And I wrote these two epistles: one I sent by an eagle to the nine and a half tribes; and the other I sent to those that were at Babylon by means of three men.
verses.77:20: And I called the eagle and spake these words unto it:
verses.77:21: 'The Most High hath made thee that thou shouldst be higher than all birds.
verses.77:22: And now go and tarry not in (any) place, nor enter a nest, nor settle upon any tree, till thou hast passed over the breadth of the many waters of the river Euphrates, and hast gone to the people that dwell there, and cast down to them this epistle.
verses.77:23: Remember, moreover, that, at the time of the deluge, Noah received from a dove the fruit of the olive, when he sent it forth from the ark.
verses.77:24: Yea, also the ravens ministered to Elijah, bearing him food, as they had been commanded. Solomon also, in the time of his kingdom, whithersoever he wished to send or seek for anything, commanded a bird (to go thither), and it obeyed him as he commanded it.
verses.77:25: And now let it not weary thee, and turn not to the right hand nor the left, but fly and go by a direct way, that thou mayst preserve the command of the Mighty One, according as I said unto thee.'
verses.78:1: These are the words of that epistle which Baruch the son of Neriah sent to the nine and a half tribes, which were across the river Euphrates, in which these things were written.
verses.78:2: Thus saith Baruch the son of Neriah to the brethren carried into captivity:
verses.78:3: 'Mercy and peace.' I bear in mind, my brethren, the love of Him who created us, who loved us from of old, and never hated us, but above all educated us.
verses.78:4: And truly I know that behold all we the twelve tribes are bound by one bond, inasmuch as we are born from one father.
verses.78:5: Wherefore I have been the more careful to leave you the words of this epistle before I die, that ye may be comforted regarding the evils which have come upon you, and that ye may be grieved also regarding the evil that has befallen your brethren; and again, also, that ye may justify His judgement which He has decreed against you that ye should be carried away captives for what ye have suffered is disproportioned to what ye have done in order that, at the last times, ye may be found worthy of your fathers.
verses.78:6: Therefore, if ye consider that ye have now suffered those things for your good, that ye may not finally be condemned and tormented, then ye will receive eternal hope; if above all ye destroy from your heart vain error, on account of which ye departed, hence.
verses.78:7: For if ye so do these things, He will continually remember you, He who always promised on our behalf to those who were more excellent than we, that He will never forget or forsake us, but with much mercy will gather together again those who were dispersed.
verses.79:1: Now, my brethren, learn first what befell Zion: how that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up against us.
verses.79:2: For we have sinned against Him who made us, and we have not kept the commandments which he commanded us,
verses.79:3: yet he hath not chastened us as we deserved.
verses.79:4: For what befell you we also suffer in a pre-eminent degree, for it befell us also.
verses.80:1: And now, my brethren, I make known unto you that when the enemy had surrounded the city, the angels of the Most High were sent, and they overthrew the fortifications of the strong wall, and they destroyed the firm iron corners, which could not be rooted out.
verses.80:2: Nevertheless, they hid all the vessels of the sanctuary, lest the enemy should get possession of them.
verses.80:3: And when they had done these things, they delivered thereupon to the enemy the overthrown wall, and the plundered house, and the burnt temple, and the people who were overcome because they were delivered up, lest the enemy should boast and say: 'Thus by force have we been able to lay waste even the house of the Most High in war.
verses.80:4: 'Your brethren also have they bound and led away to Babylon, and have caused, them to dwell there.
verses.80:5: But we have been left here, being very few.
verses.80:6: This is the tribulation about which I wrote to you.
verses.80:7: For assuredly I know that (the consolation of) the inhabitants of Zion consoleth you: so far as ye knew that it was prospered (your consolation) was greater than the tribulation which ye endured in having to depart from it.
verses.81:1: But regarding consolation, hear ye the word.
verses.81:2: For I was mourning regarding Zion, and I prayed for mercy from the Most High, and I said:
verses.81:3: 'How long will these things endure for us? And will these evils come upon us always?'
verses.81:4: And the Mighty One did according to the multitude of His mercies, And the Most High according to the greatness of His compassion, And He revealed unto me the word, that I might receive consolation, And He showed me visions that I should not again endure anguish, And He made known to me the mystery of the times. And the advent of the hours he showed me.
verses.82:1: Therefore, my brethren, I have written to you, that ye may comfort yourselves regarding the multitude of your tribulations.
verses.82:2: For know ye that our Maker will assuredly avenge us on all our enemies, according to all that they have done to us, also that the consummation which the Most High will make is very nigh, and His mercy that is coming, and the consummation of His judgement is by no means far off.
verses.82:3: For lo! we see now the multitude of the prosperity of the Gentiles, Though they act impiously, But they shall be like a vapour:
verses.82:4: And we behold the multitude of their power, Though they do wickedly, But they shall be made like unto a drop:
verses.82:5: And we see the firmness of their might. Though they resist the Mighty One every hour, But they shall be accounted as spittle.
verses.82:6: And we consider the glory of their greatness, Though they do not keep the statutes of the Most High, But as smoke shall they pass away.
verses.82:7: And we meditate on the beauty of theirs gracefulness, Though they have to do with pollutions, But as grass that withers shall they fade away.
verses.82:8: And we consider the strength of their cruelty, Though they remember not the end (thereof), But as a wave that passes shall they be broken.
verses.82:9: And we remark the boastfulness of their might, Though they deny the beneficence of God, who gave (it) to them, But they shall pass away as a passing cloud.
verses.83:1: [For the Most High will assuredly hasten His times, And He will assuredly bring on His hours.
verses.83:2: And He will assuredly judge those who are in His world, And will visit in truth all things by means of all their hidden works.
verses.83:3: And He will assuredly examine the secret thoughts, And that which is laid up in the secret chambers of all the members of man. And will make (them) manifest in the presence of all with reproof.
verses.83:4: Let none therefore of these present things ascend into your hearts, but above all let us be expectant, because that which is promised to us shall come.
verses.83:5: And let us not now look unto the delights of the Gentiles in the present,
verses.83:6: but let us remember what has been promised to us in the end. For the ends of the times and of the seasons and whatsoever is with them shall assuredly pass by together.
verses.83:7: The consummation, moreover, of the age shall then show the great might of its ruler, when all things come to judgement.
verses.83:8: Do ye therefore prepare your hearts for that which before ye believed, lest ye come to be in bondage in both worlds, so that ye be led away captive here and be tormented there.
verses.83:9: For that which exists now or which has passed away, or which is to come, in all these things, neither is the evil fully evil, nor again the good fully good.
verses.83:10: For all healthinesses of this time are turning into diseases,
verses.83:11: And all might of this time is turning into weakness, And all the force of this time is turning into impotence, And every energy of youth is turning into old age and consummation.
verses.83:12: And every beauty of gracefulness of this time is turning faded and hateful,
verses.83:13: And every proud dominion of the present is turning into humiliation and shame, And every praise of the glory of this time is turning into the shame of silence,
verses.83:14: And every vain splendour and insolence of this time is turning into voiceless ruin.
verses.83:15: And every delight and joy of this time is turning to worms and corruption,
verses.83:16: And every clamour of the pride of this time is turning into dust and stillness.
verses.83:17: And every possession of riches of this time is being turned into Sheol alone,
verses.83:18: And all the rapine of passion of this time is turning into involuntary death, And every passion of the lusts of this time is turning into a judgement of torment.
verses.83:19: And every artifice and craftiness of this time is turning into a proof of the truth,
verses.83:20: And every sweetness of unguents of this time is turning into judgement and condemnation,
verses.83:21: And every love of lying is turning to contumely through truth.
verses.83:22: Since therefore all these things are done now, does anyone think that they will not be avenged;
verses.83:23: But the consummation of all things will come to the truth.]
verses.84:1: Behold! I have therefore made known unto you (these things) whilst I live: for I have said (it) that ye should learn the things that are excellent; for the Mighty One hath commanded me to instruct you: and I will set before you some of the commandments of His judgement before I die.
verses.84:2: Remember that formerly Moses assuredly called heaven and earth to witness against you and said:'If ye transgress the law ye shall be dispersed, but if ye keep it ye shall be kept.'
verses.84:3: And other things also he used to say unto you when ye the twelve tribes were together in the desert.
verses.84:4: And after his death ye cast them away from you: on this account there came upon you what had been predicted.
verses.84:5: And now Moses used to tell you before they befell you, and lo! they have befallen you: for ye have forsaken the law.
verses.84:6: Lo! I also say unto you after ye have suffered, that if ye obey those things which have been said unto you, ye will receive from the Mighty One whatever has been laid up and reserved for you.
verses.84:7: Moreover, let this epistle be for a testimony between me and you, that ye may remember the commandments of the Mighty One, and that also there may be to me a defence in the presence of Him who sent me.
verses.84:8: And remember ye the law and Zion, and the holy land and your brethren, and the covenant of your fathers, and forget not the festivals and the sabbaths.
verses.84:9: And deliver ye this epistle and the traditions of the law to your sons after you, as also your fathers delivered (them) to you.
verses.84:10: And at all times make request perseveringly and pray diligently with your whole heart that the Mighty One may be reconciled to you, and that He may not reckon the multitude of your sins, but remember the rectitude of your fathers.
verses.84:11: For if He judge us not according to the multitude of His mercies, woe unto all us who are born.
verses.85:1: [Know ye, moreover, that In former times and in the generations of old our fathers had helpers, Righteous men and holy prophets:
verses.85:2: Nay more, we were in our own land [And they helped us when we sinned], And they interceded for us with Him who made us, [Because they trusted in their works], And the Mighty One heard their prayer and forgave us.
verses.85:3: But now the righteous have been gathered And the prophets have fallen asleep, And we also have gone forth from the land, And Zion has been taken from us, And we have nothing now save the Mighty One and His law.
verses.85:4: If therefore we direct and dispose our hearts, We shall receive everything that we lost, And much better things than we lost by many times.
verses.85:5: For what we have lost was subject to corruption, And what we shall receive shall not be corruptible.
verses.85:6: [Moreover, also, I have written thus to our brethren to Babylon, that to them also I may attest these very things.]
verses.85:7: And let all those things aforesaid be always before your eyes, Because we are still in the spirit and the power of our liberty.
verses.85:8: Again, moreover, the Most High also is long-suffering towards us here, And He hath shown to us that which is to be, And hath not concealed from us what will befall in the end.
verses.85:9: Before therefore judgement exact its own, And truth that which is its due, Let us prepare our soul That we may possess, and not be taken possession of, And that we may hope and not be put to shame, And that we may rest with our fathers, and not be tormented with our enemies.
verses.85:10: For the youth of the world is past, And the strength of the creation already exhausted, And the advent of the times is very short, Yea, they have passed by; And the pitcher is near to the cistern, And the ship to the port, And the course of the journey to the city, And life to (its) consummation.
verses.85:11: And again prepare your souls, so that when ye sail and ascend from the ship ye may have rest and not be condemned when ye depart.
verses.85:12: For lo! when the Most High will bring to pass all these things, There shall not there be again [a place of repentance, nor] a limit to the times, Nor a duration for the hours, Nor a change of ways, Nor place for prayer, Nor sending of petitions, Nor receiving of knowledge, Nor giving of love, Nor place of repentance for the soul, Nor supplication for offences, Nor intercession of the fathers, Nor prayer of the prophets, Nor help of the righteous.
verses.85:13: There there is the sentence of corruption, The way of fire, And the path which bringeth to Gehenna.
verses.85:14: On this account there is one law by one, One age and an end for all who are in it.
verses.85:15: Then He will preserve those whom He can forgive, And at the same time destroy those who are polluted with sins.]
verses.86:1: When therefore ye receive this my epistle, read it in your congregations with care.
verses.86:2: And meditate thereon, above all on the days of your fasts.
verses.86:3: And bear me in mind by means of this epistle, as I also bear you in mind in it, and always. Fare ye well.
verses.87:1: And it came to pass when I had ended all the words of this epistle, and had written it sedulously to its close, that I folded it, and sealed it carefully, and bound it to the neck of the eagle, and dismissed and sent it.

verses.0:0: A revelation of Baruch, who stood upon the river Gel weeping over the captivity of Jerusalem, when also Abimelech was preserved by the hand of God, at the farm of Agrippa. And he was sitting thus at the beautiful gates, where the Holy of holies lay.
verses.1:1: Verily I Baruch was weeping in my mind and sorrowing on account of the people, and that Nebuchadnezzar the king was permitted by God to destroy His city, saying:
verses.1:2: Lord, why didst Thou set on fire Thy vineyard, and lay it waste? Why didst Thou do this? And why, Lord, didst Thou not requite us with another chastisement, but didst deliver us to nations such as these, so that they reproach us and say, Where is their God?
verses.1:3: And behold as I was weeping and saying such things, I saw an angel of the Lord coming and saying to me: Understand, O man, greatly beloved, and trouble not thyself so greatly concerning the salvation of Jerusalem, for thus saith the Lord God, the Almighty.
verses.1:4: For He sent me before thee, to make known and to show to thee all (the things) of God.
verses.1:5: For thy prayer was heard before Him, and entered into the ears of the Lord God.
verses.1:6: And when he had said these things to me, I was silent. And the angel said to me: Cease to provoke God, and I will show thee other mysteries, greater than these.
verses.1:7: And I Baruch said, As the Lord God liveth, if thou wilt show me, and I hear a word of thine, I will not continue to speak any longer. God shall add to my judgement in the day of judgement, if I speak hereafter. And the angel of the powers said to me, Come, and I will show thee the mysteries of God.
verses.2:1: And he took me and led me where the firmament has been set fast, and where there was a river which no one can cross, nor any strange breeze of all those which God created. And he took me and led me to the first heaven, and showed me a door of great size.
verses.2:2: And he said to me, Let us enter through it, and we entered as though borne on wings, a distance of about thirty days' journey. And he showed me within the heaven a plain;
verses.2:3: And there were men dwelling thereon, with the faces of oxen, and the horns of stags and the feet of goats, and the haunches of lambs.
verses.2:4: And I Baruch asked the angel, Make known to me, I pray thee, what is the thickness of the heaven in which we journeyed, or what is its extent, or what is the plain, in order that I may also tell the sons of men?
verses.2:5: And the angel whose name is Phamael said to me: This door which thou seest is the door of heaven, and as great as is the distance from earth to heaven, so great also is its thickness; and again as great as is the distance (from North to South, so great) is the length of the plain which thou didst see.
verses.2:6: And again the angel of the powers said to me, Come, and I will show thee greater mysteries.
verses.2:7: But I said, I pray thee show me what are these men. And he said to me, These are they who built the tower of strife against God, and the Lord banished them.
verses.3:1: And the angel of the Lord took me and led me to a second heaven.
verses.3:2: And he showed me there also a door like the first and said, Let us enter through it.
verses.3:3: And we entered, being borne on wings a distance of about sixty days' journey.
verses.3:4: And he showed me there also a plain, and it was full of men, whose appearance was like that of dogs, and whose feet were like those of stags.
verses.3:5: And I asked the angel: I pray thee, Lord, say to me who are these.
verses.3:6: And he said, These are they who gave counsel to build the tower, for they whom thou seest drove forth multitudes of both men and women, to make bricks; among whom, a woman making bricks was not allowed to be released in the hour of child-birth, but brought forth while she was making bricks, and carried her child in her apron, and continued to make bricks. And the Lord appeared to them and confused their speech, when they had built the tower to the height of four hundred and sixty-three cubits.
verses.3:7: And they took a gimlet, and sought to pierce the heaven, saying,
verses.3:8: Let us see (whether) the heaven is made of clay, or of brass, or of iron. When God saw this He did not permit them, but smote them with blindness and confusion of speech, and rendered them as thou seest.
verses.4:1: And I Baruch said, Behold, Lord, Thou didst show me great and wonderful things; and now show me all things for the sake of the Lord.
verses.4:2: And the angel said to me, Come, let us proceed. (And I proceeded) with the angel from that place about one hundred and eighty-five days' journey.
verses.4:3: And he showed me a plain and a serpent, which appeared to be two hundred plethra in length.
verses.4:4: And he showed me Hades, and its appearance was dark and abominable.
verses.4:5: And I said, Who is this dragon, and who is this monster around him?
verses.4:6: And the angel said, The dragon is he who eats the bodies of those who spend their life wickedly, and he is nourished by them. And this is Hades, which itself also closely resembles him, in that it also drinks about a cubit from the sea, which does not sink at all.
verses.4:7:
Baruch said, And how (does this happen)? And the angel said, Hearken, the Lord God made three hundred and sixty rivers, of which the chief of all are Alphias, Abyrus, and the Gericus;
[4:and] because of these the sea does not sink.
verses.4:8: And I said, I pray thee show me which is the tree which led Adam astray.
verses.4:9: And the angel said to me, It is the vine, which the angel Sammael planted, whereat the Lord God was angry, and He cursed him and his plant, while also on this account He did not permit Adam to touch it, and therefore the devil being envious deceived him through his vine.
verses.4:10: [And I Baruch said, Since also the vine has been the cause of such great evil, and is under judgment of the curse of God, and was the destruction of the first created, how is it now so useful?
verses.4:11: And the angel said, Thou askest aright. When God caused the deluge upon earth, and destroyed all flesh, and four hundred and nine thousand giants, and the water rose fifteen cubits above the highest mountains, then the water entered into paradise and destroyed every flower; but it removed wholly without the bounds the shoot of the vine and cast it outside. And when the earth appeared out of the water, and Noah came out of the ark, he began to plant of the plants which he found.
verses.4:12: But he found also the shoot of the vine; and he took it, and was reasoning in himself, What then is it?
verses.4:13: And I came and spake to him the things concerning it. And he said, Shall I plant it, or what shall I do? Since Adam was destroyed because of it, let me not also meet with the anger of God because of it.
verses.4:14: And saying these things he prayed that God would reveal to him what he should do concerning it. And when he had completed the prayer which lasted forty days, and having besought many things and wept, he said:
verses.4:15:
Lord, I entreat thee to reveal to me what I shall do concerning this plant. But God sent his angel Sarasael, and said to him, Arise, Noah, and plant the shoot of the vine, for thus saith the Lord : Its bitterness shall be changed into sweetness, and its curse shall become a blessing, and that which is produced from it shall become the blood of God; and as through it the human race obtained condemnation, so again through Jesus Christ the Immanuel will they receive in Him the upward calling,
[4:and] the entry into paradise].
verses.4:16: Know therefore, O Baruch, that as Adam through this very tree obtained condemnation, and was divested of the glory of God, so also the men who now drink insatiably the wine which is begotten of it, transgress worse than Adam, and are far from the glory of God, and are surrendering themselves to the eternal fire.
verses.4:17: For (no) good comes through it. For those who drink it to surfeit do these things: neither does a brother pity his brother, nor a father his son, nor children their parents, but from the drinking of wine come all evils, such as murders, adulteries, fornications, perjuries, thefts, and such like. And nothing good is established by it.
verses.5:1: And I Baruch said to the angel, Let me ask thee one thing, Lord.
verses.5:2: Since thou didst say to me that the dragon drinks one cubit out of the sea, say to me also, how great is his belly?
verses.5:3: And the angel said, His belly is Hades; and as far as a plummet is thrown (by) three hundred men, so great is his belly. Come, then, that I may show thee also greater works than these.
verses.6:1: And he took me and led me where the sun goes forth; and he showed me a chariot and four, under which burnt a fire, and in the chariot was sitting a man, wearing a crown of fire, (and) the chariot (was) drawn by forty angels.
verses.6:2: And behold a bird circling before the sun, about nine cubits away.
verses.6:3: And I said to the angel, What is this bird?
verses.6:4: And he said to me, This is the guardian of the earth.
verses.6:5: And I said, Lord, how is he the guardian of the earth? Teach me.
verses.6:6: And the angel said to me, This bird flies alongside of the sun, and expanding his wings receives its fiery rays. For if he were not receiving them, the human race would not be preserved, nor any other living creature. But God appointed this bird thereto.
verses.6:7: And he expanded his wings, and I saw on his right wing very large letters, as large as the space of a threshing-floor, the size of about four thousand modii;
verses.6:8: and the letters were of gold. And the angel said to me, Read them.
verses.6:9: And I read and they ran thus: Neither earth nor heaven bring me forth, but wings of fire bring me forth. And I said, Lord, what is this bird, and what is his name?
verses.6:11: And the angel said to me, His name is called Phoenix. (And I said), And what does he eat? And he said to me, The manna of heaven and the dew of earth.
verses.6:12: And I said, Does the bird excrete? And he said to me, He excretes a worm, and the excrement of the worm is cinnamon, which kings and princes use. But wait and thou shalt see the glory of God.
verses.6:13: And while he was conversing with me, there was as a thunder-clap, and the place was shaken on which we were standing. And I asked the angel, My Lord, what is this sound?
verses.6:14: And the angel said to me, Even now the angels are opening the three hundred and sixty-five gates of heaven, and the light is being separated from the darkness. And a voice came which said, Light giver, give to the world radiance.
verses.6:15: And when I heard the noise of the bird, I said, Lord, what is this noise?
verses.6:16: And he said, This is the bird who awakens from slumber the cocks upon earth. For as men do through the mouth, so also does the cock signify to those in the world, in his own speech. For the sun is made ready by the angels, and the cock crows.
verses.7:1: And I said, And where does the sun begin its labors, after the cock crows?
verses.7:2: And the angel said to me, Listen, Baruch: All things whatsoever I showed thee are in the first and second heaven, and in the third heaven the sun passes through and gives light to the world.
verses.7:3: But wait, and thou shalt see the glory of God. And while I was conversing with him, I saw the bird, and he appeared in front, and grew less and less, and at length returned to his full size.
verses.7:4: And behind him I saw the shining sun, and the angels which draw it, and a crown upon its bead, the sight of which we were not able to gaze Upon, and behold.
verses.7:5: And as soon as the sun shone, the Phoenix also stretched out his wings.
verses.7:6: But I, when I beheld such great glory, was brought low with great fear, and I fled and hid in the wings of the angel. And the angel said to me, Fear not, Baruch, but wait and thou shalt also see their setting.
verses.8:1: And he took me and led me towards the west; and when the time of the, setting came,
verses.8:2: I saw again the bird coming before it, and as soon as lie came I saw the angels, and they lifted the crown from its head.
verses.8:3: But the bird stood exhausted and with wings contracted.
verses.8:4: And beholding these things, I said, Lord, wherefore did they lift the crown from the head of the sun,and wherefore is the bird so exhausted?
verses.8:5: And the angel said to me, The crown of the sun, when it has run through the day, four angels take it, and bear it up to heaven, and renew it, because it and its rays have been defiled upon earth; moreover it is so renewed each day.
verses.8:6: And I Baruch said, Lord, and wherefore are its beams defiled upon earth? And the angel said to me, Because it beholds the lawlessness and unrighteousness of men, namely fornications, adulteries, thefts, extortions, idolatries, drunkenness, murders, strife, jealousies, evil-speakings, murmurings, whisperings, divinations, and such like, which are not well-pleasing to God. On account of these things is it defiled, and therefore is it renewed.
verses.8:7: But thou askest concerning the bird, how it is exhausted. Because by restraining the rays of the sun through the fire and burning heat of the whole day, it is exhausted thereby. For, as we said before, unless his wings were screening the rays of the sun, no living creature would be preserved.
verses.9:1: And they having retired, the night also fell, and at the same time came the chariot of the moon, along with the stars.
verses.9:2: And I Baruch said, Lord, show me it also, I beseech of thee, how it goes forth, where it departs, and in what form it moves along. And the angel said, Wait' and thou shalt see it also shortly.
verses.9:3: And on the morrow I also saw it in the form of a woman, and sitting on a wheeled chariot. And there were before it oxen and lambs in the chariot, and a multitude of angels in like manner.
verses.9:4: And I said, Lord, what are the oxen and the lambs? And he said to me, They also are angels.
verses.9:5: And again I asked, Why is it that it at one time increases, but at another time decreases?
verses.9:6: And (he said to me), Listen, O Baruch: This which thou seest had been written by God beautiful as no other.
verses.9:7: And at the transgression of the first Adam, it was near to Sammael when he took the serpent as a garment. And it did not hide itself but increased, and God was angry with it, and afflicted it, and shortened its days.
verses.9:8: And I said, And how does it not also shine always, but only in the night?
verses.9:9: And the angel said, Listen: as in the presence of a king, the courtiers cannot speak freely, so the moon and the stars cannot shine in the presence of the sun; for the stars are always suspended, but they are screened by the sun, and the moon, although it is uninjured, is consumed by the heat of the sun.
verses.10:1: And when I had learnt all these things from the archangel, he took and led me into a fourth heaven.
verses.10:2: And I saw a monotonous plain, and in the middle of it a pool of water.
verses.10:3: And there were in it multitudes of birds of all kinds, but not like those here on earth.
verses.10:4: But I saw a crane as great as great oxen; and all the birds were great beyond those in the world.
verses.10:5: And I asked the angel, What is the plain, and what the pool, and what the multitudes of birds around it?
verses.10:6: And the angel said, Listen, Baruch : The plain which contains in it the pool and other wonders is the place where the souls of the righteous come, when they hold converse, living together in choirs. But the water is that which the clouds receive, and rain upon the earth, and the fruits increase.
verses.10:7: And I said again to the angel of the Lord, But (what) are these birds? And he said to me, They are those which continually sing praise to the Lord.
verses.10:8: And I said, Lord, and how do men say that the water which descends in rain is from the sea?
verses.10:9: And the angel said, The water which descends in rain -- this also is from the sea, and from the waters upon earth; but that which stimulates the fruits is (only) from the latter source.
verses.10:10: Know therefore henceforth that from this source is what is called the dew of heaven.
verses.11:1: And the angel took me and led me thence to a fifth heaven. And the gate was closed.
verses.11:2: And I said, Lord, is not this gate-way open that we may enter? And the angel said to me, We cannot enter until Michael comes, who holds the keys of the Kingdom of Heaven; but wait and thou shalt see the glory of God.
verses.11:3: And there was a great sound, as thunder. And I said, Lord, what is this sound?
verses.11:4: And he said to me, Even now Michael, the commander of the angels, comes down to receive the prayers of men. And behold a voice came, Let the gates be opened.
verses.11:5: And they opened them, and there was a roar as of thunder.
verses.11:6: And Michael came, and the angel who was with me came face to face with him and said, Hail, my commander, and that of all our order.
verses.11:7: And the commander Michael said, Hail thou also, our brother, and the interpreter of the revelations to those who pass through life virtuously.
verses.11:8: And having saluted one another thus, they stood still. And I saw the commander Michael, holding an exceedingly great vessel; its depth was as great as the distance from heaven to earth, and its breadth as great as the distance from north to south. And I said, Lord, what is that which Michael the archangel is holding?
verses.11:9: And he said to me, This is where the merits of the righteous enter, and such good works as they do, which are escorted before the heavenly God.
verses.12:1: And as I was conversing with them, behold angels came bearing baskets full of flowers. And they gave them to Michael.
verses.12:2: And I asked the angel, Lord, who are these, and what are the things brought hither from beside them?
verses.12:3: And he said to me, These are angels (who) are over the righteous.
verses.12:4: And the archangel took the baskets, and cast them into the vessel.
verses.12:5: And the angel said to me, These flowers are the merits of the righteous.
verses.12:6: And I saw other angels bearing baskets which were (neither) empty-nor full. And they began to lament, and did not venture to draw near, because they had not the prizes complete.
verses.12:7: And Michael cried and said, Come hither, also, ye angels, bring what ye have brought.
verses.12:8: And Michael was exceedingly grieved, and the angel who was with me, because they did not fill the vessel.
verses.13:1: And then came in like manner other angels weeping and bewailing, and saying with fear, Behold how we are overclouded, O Lord, for we were delivered to evil men, and we wish to depart from them.
verses.13:2: And Michael said, Ye cannot depart from them, in order that the enemy may not prevail to the end; but say to me what ye ask.
verses.13:3: And they said, We pray thee, Michael our commander, transfer us from them, for we cannot abide with wicked and foolish men, for there is nothing good in them, but every kind of unrighteousness and greed.
verses.13:4: For we do not behold them entering [into Church at all, nor among spiritual fathers, nor] into any good work. But where there is murder, there also are they in the midst, and where are fornications, adulteries, thefts, slanders, perjuries, jealousies, drunkenness, strife, envy, murmurings, whispering, idolatry, divination, and such like, then are they workers of such works, and of others worse.
verses.13:5: Wherefore we entreat that we may depart from them. And Michael said to the angels, Wait till I learn from the Lord what shall come to pass.
verses.14:1: And in that very hour Michael departed, and the doors were closed. And there was a sound as thunder.
verses.14:2: And I asked the angel, What is the sound?
verses.14:3: And he said to me, Michael is even now presenting the merits of men to God.
verses.15:1: And in that very hour Michael descended, and the gate was opened; and he brought oil.
verses.15:2: And as for the angels which brought the baskets which were full, he filled them with oil, saying, Take it away, reward our friends an hundredfold, and those who have laboriously wrought good works.
verses.15:3: For those who sowed virtuously, also reap virtuously. And he said also to those bringing the half-empty baskets, Come hither ye also; take away the reward according as ye brought, and deliver it to the sons of men.
verses.15:4: [Then he said also to those who brought the full and to those who brought the half-empty baskets: Go and bless our friends, and say to them that thus saith the Lord, Ye are faithful over a few things, I will set you over many things; enter into the joy of your Lord.]
verses.16:1: And turning he said also to those who brought nothing:
verses.16:2: Thus saith the Lord, Be not sad of countenance, and weep not, nor let the sons of men alone. But since they angered me in their works, go and make them envious and angry and provoked against a people that is no people, a people that has no understanding.
verses.16:3: Further, besides these, send forth the caterpillar and the unwinged locust, and the mildew, and the common locust (and) hail with lightnings and anger, and punish them severely with the sword and with death, and their children with demons.
verses.16:4: For they did not hearken to my voice, nor did they observe my commandments, nor do them, but were despisers of my commandments, and insolent towards the priests who proclaimed my words to them.
verses.17:1: And while he yet spake, the door was closed, and we withdrew.
verses.17:2: And the angel took me and restored me to the place where I was at the beginning.
verses.17:3: And having come to myself, I gave glory to God, who counted me worthy of such honor.
verses.17:4: Wherefore do ye also, brethren, who obtained such a revelation, yourselves also glorify God, so that He also may glorify you, now and ever, and to all eternity. Amen.

verses.1:1: It came to pass, when the children of Israel were taken captive by the king of the Chaldeans, that God spoke to Jeremiah saying: Jeremiah, my chosen one, arise and depart from this city, you and Baruch, since I am going to destroy it because of the multitude of the sins of those who dwell in it.
verses.1:2: For your prayers are like a solid pillar in its midst, and like an indestructible wall surrounding it.
verses.1:3: Now, then, arise and depart before the host of the Chaldeans surrounds it.
verses.1:4: And Jeremiah answered, saying: I beseech you, Lord, permit me, your servant, to speak in your presence.
verses.1:5: And the Lord said to him: Speak, my chosen one Jeremiah.
verses.1:6: And Jeremiah spoke, saying: Lord Almighty, would you deliver the chosen city into the hands of the Chaldeans, so that the king with the multitude of his people might boast and say: "I have prevailed over the holy city of God"?
verses.1:7: No, my Lord, but if it is your will, let it be destroyed by your hands.
verses.1:8: And the Lord said to Jeremiah: Since you are my chosen one, arise and depart form this city, you and Baruch, for I am going to destroy it because of the multitude of the sins of those who dwell in it.
verses.1:9: For neither the king nor his host will be able to enter it unless I first open its gates.
verses.1:10: Arise, then, and go to Baruch, and tell him these words.
verses.1:11: And when you have arisen at the sixth hour of the night, go out on the city walls and I will show you that unless I first destroy the city, they cannot enter it.
verses.1:12: When the Lord had said this, he departed from Jeremiah.
verses.2:1: And Jeremiah ran and told these things to Baruch; and as they went into the temple of God, Jeremiah tore his garments and put dust on his head and entered the holy place of God.
verses.2:2: And when Baruch saw him with dust sprinkled on his head and his garments torn, he cried out in a loud voice, saying: Father Jeremiah, what are you doing? What sin has the people committed?
verses.2:3: (For whenever the people sinned, Jeremiah would sprinkle dust on his head and would pray for the people until their sin was forgiven.)
verses.2:4: So Baruch asked him, saying: Father, what is this?
verses.2:5: And Jeremiah said to him: Refrain from rending your garments -- rather, let us rend our hearts! And let us not draw water for the trough, but let us weep and fill them with tears! For the Lord will not have mercy on this people.
verses.2:6: And Baruch said: Father Jeremiah, what has happened?
verses.2:7: And Jeremiah said: God is delivering the city into the hands of the king of the Chaldeans, to take the people captive into Babylon.
verses.2:8: And when Baruch heard these things, he also tore his garments and said: Father Jeremiah, who has made this known to you?
verses.2:9: And Jeremiah said to him: Stay with me awhile, until the sixth hour of the night, so that you may know that this word is true.
verses.2:10: Therefore they both remained in the altar-area weeping, and their garments were torn.
verses.3:1: And when the hour of the night arrived, as the Lord had told Jeremiah they came up together on the walls of the city, Jeremiah and Baruch.
verses.3:2: And behold, there came a sound of trumpets; and angels emerged from heaven holding torches in their hands, and they set them on the walls of the city.
verses.3:3: And when Jeremiah and Baruch saw them, they wept, saying: Now we know that the word is true!
verses.3:4: And Jeremiah besought the angels, saying: I beseech you, do not destroy the city yet, until I say something to the Lord.
verses.3:5: And the Lord spoke to the angels, saying: Do not destroy the city until I speak to my chosen one, Jeremiah.
verses.3:6: Then Jeremiah spoke, saying: I beg you, Lord, bid me to speak in your presence.
verses.3:7: And the Lord said: Speak, my chosen one Jeremiah.
verses.3:8: And Jeremiah said: Behold, Lord, now we know that you are delivering the city into the hands of its enemies, and they will take the people away to Babylon. What do you want me to do with the holy vessels of the temple service?
verses.3:10: And the Lord said to him: Take them and consign them to the earth, saying: Hear, Earth, the voice of your creator who formed you in the abundance of waters, who sealed you with seven seals for seven epochs, and after this you will receive your ornaments (?) --
verses.3:11: Guard the vessels of the temple service until the gathering of the beloved.
verses.3:12: And Jeremiah spoke, saying: I beseech you, Lord, show me what I should do for Abimelech the Ethiopian, for he has done many kindnesses to your servant Jeremiah.
verses.3:13: For he pulled me out of the miry pit; and I do not wish that he should see the destruction and desolation of this city, but that you should be merciful to him and that he should not be grieved.
verses.3:14: And the Lord said to Jeremiah: Send him to the vineyard of Agrippa, and I will hide him in the shadow of the mountain until I cause the people to return to the city.
verses.3:15: And you, Jeremiah, go with your people into Babylon and stay with them, preaching to them, until I cause them to return to the city.
verses.3:16: But leave Baruch here until I speak with him.
verses.3:17: When he had said these things, the Lord ascended from Jeremiah into heaven.
verses.3:18: But Jeremiah and Baruch entered the holy place, and taking the vessels of the temple service, they consigned them to the earth as the Lord had told them.
verses.3:19: And immediately the earth swallowed them.
verses.3:20: And they both sat down and wept.
verses.3:21: And when morning came, Jeremiah sent Abimelech, saying: Take a basket and go to the estate of Agrippa by the mountain road, and bring back some figs to give to the sick among the people; for the favor of the Lord is on you and his glory is on your head.
verses.3:22: And when he had said this, Jeremiah sent him away; and Abimelech went as he told him.
verses.4:1: And when morning came, behold the host of the Chaldeans surrounded the city.
verses.4:2: And the great angel trumpeted, saying: Enter the city, host of the Chaldeans; for behold, the gate is opened for you.
verses.4:3: Therefore let the king enter, with his multitudes, and let him take all the people captive.
verses.4:4: But taking the keys of the temple, Jeremiah went outside the city and threw them away in the presence of the sun, saying: I say to you, Sun, take the keys of the temple of God and guard them until the day in which the Lord asks you for them.
verses.4:5: For we have not been found worthy to keep them, for we have become unfaithful guardians.
verses.4:6: While Jeremiah was still weeping for the people, they brought him out with the people and dragged them into Babylon.
verses.4:7: But Baruch put dust on his head and sat and wailed this lamentation, saying: Why has Jerusalem been devastated? Because of the sins of the beloved people she was delivered into the hands of enemies -- because of our sins and those of the people.
verses.4:8: But let not the lawless ones boast and say: "We were strong enough to take the city of God by our might;" but it was delivered to you because of our sins.
verses.4:9: And God will pity us and cause us to return to our city, but you will not survive!
verses.4:10: Blessed are our fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, for they departed from this world and did not see the destruction of this city.
verses.4:11: When he had said this, Baruch departed from the city, weeping and saying: Grieving because of you, Jerusalem, I went out from you.
verses.4:12: And he remained sitting in a tomb, while the angels came to him and explained to him everything that the Lord revealed to him through them.
verses.5:1: But Abimelech took the figs in the burning heat; and coming upon a tree, he sat under its shade to rest a bit.
verses.5:2: And leaning his head on the basket of figs, he fell asleep and slept for 66 years; and he was not awakened from his slumber.
verses.5:3: And afterward, when he awoke from his sleep, he said: I slept sweetly for a little while, but my head is heavy because I did not get enough sleep.
verses.5:4: Then he uncovered the basket of figs and found them dripping milk.
verses.5:5: And he said: I would like to sleep a little longer, because my head is heavy. But I am afraid that I might fall asleep and be late in awakening and my father Jeremiah would think badly of me; for if he were not in a hurry, he would not have sent me today at daybreak.
verses.5:6: So I will get up, and proceed in the burning heat; for isn't there heat, isn't there toil every day?
verses.5:7: So he got up and took the basket of figs and placed it on his shoulders, and he entered into Jerusalem and did not recognize it -- neither his own house, nor the place -- nor did he find his own family or any of his acquaintances.
verses.5:8: And he said: The Lord be blessed, for a great trance has come over me today!
verses.5:9: This is not the city Jerusalem -- and I have lost my way because I came by the mountain road when I arose from my sleep; and since my head was heavy because I did not get enough sleep, I lost my way.
verses.5:10: It will seem incredible to Jeremiah that I lost my way!
verses.5:11: And he departed from the city; and as he searched he saw the landmarks of the city, and he said: Indeed, this is the city; I lost my way.
verses.5:12: And again he returned to the city and searched, and found no one of his own people; and he said: The Lord be blessed, for a great trance has come over me!
verses.5:13: And again he departed from the city, and he stayed there grieving, not knowing where he should go.
verses.5:14: And he put down the basket, saying: I will sit here until the Lord takes this trance from me.
verses.5:15: And as he sat, he saw an old man coming from the field; and Abimelech said to him: I say to you, old man, what city is this?
verses.5:16: And he said to him: It is Jerusalem.
verses.5:17: And Abimelech said to him: Where is Jeremiah the priest, and Baruch the secretary, and all the people of this city, for I could not find them?
verses.5:18: And the old man said to him: Are you not from this city, seeing that you remember Jeremiah today, because you are asking about him after such a long time?
verses.5:19: For Jeremiah is in Babylon with the people; for they were taken captive by king Nebuchadnezzar, and Jeremiah is with them to preach the good news to them and to teach them the word.
verses.5:20: As soon as Abimelech heard this from the old man, he said: If you were not an old man, and if it were not for the fact that it is not lawful for a man to upbraid one older than himself, I would laugh at you and say that you are out of your mind -- since you say that the people have been taken captive into Babylon.
verses.5:21: Even if the heavenly torrents had descended on them, there has not yet been time for them to go into Babylon!
verses.5:22: For how much time has passed since my father Jeremiah sent me to the estate of Agrippa to bring a few figs, so that I might give them to the sick among the people?
verses.5:23: And I went and got them, and when I came to a certain tree in the burning heat, I sat to rest a little; and I leaned my head on the basket and fell asleep.
verses.5:24: And when I awoke I uncovered the basket of figs, supposing that I was late; and I found the figs dripping milk, just as I had collected them.
verses.5:25: But you claim that the people have been taken captive into Babylon.
verses.5:26: But that you might know, take the figs and see!
verses.5:27: And he uncovered the basket of figs for the old man, and he saw them dripping milk.
verses.5:28: And when the old man saw them, he said: O my son, you are a righteous man, and God did not want you to see the desolation of the city, so he brought this trance upon you.
verses.5:29: For behold it is 66 years today since the people were taken captive into Babylon.
verses.5:30: But that you might learn, my son, that what I tell you is true -- look into the field and see that the ripening of the crops has not appeared.
verses.5:31: And notice that the figs are not in season, and be enlightened.
verses.5:32: Then Abimelech cried out in a loud voice, saying: I bless you, God of heaven and earth, the Rest of the souls of the righteous in every place!
verses.5:33: Then he said to the old man: What month is this?
verses.5:34: And he said: Nisan (which is Abib).
verses.5:35: And taking some of figs, he gave them to the old man and said to him: May God illumine your way to the city above, Jerusalem. 6
verses.6:1: After this, Abimelech went out of the city and prayed to the Lord.
verses.6:2: And behold, an angel of the Lord came and took him by the right hand and brought him back to where Baruch was sitting, and he found him in a tomb.
verses.6:3: And when they saw each other, they both wept and kissed each other.
verses.6:4: But when Baruch looked up he saw with his own eyes the figs that were covered in Abimelech's basket.
verses.6:5: And lifting his eyes to heaven, he prayed, saying:
verses.6:6: You are the God who gives a reward to those who love you. Prepare yourself, my heart, and rejoice and be glad while you are in your tabernacle, saying to your fleshly house, "your grief has been changed to joy;" for the Sufficient One is coming and will deliver you in your tabernacle -- for there is no sin in you.
verses.6:7: Revive in your tabernacle, in your virginal faith, and believe that you will live!
verses.6:8: Look at this basket of figs -- for behold, they are 66 years old and have not become shrivelled or rotten, but they are dripping milk.
verses.6:9: So it will be with you, my flesh, if you do what is commanded you by the angel of righteousness.
verses.6:10: He who preserved the basket of figs, the same will again preserve you by his power.
verses.6:11: When Baruch had said this, he said to Abimelech: Stand up and let us pray that the Lord may make known to us how we shall be able to send to Jeremiah in Babylon the report about the shelter provided for you on the way.
verses.6:12: And Baruch prayed, saying: Lord God, our strength is the elect light which comes forth from your mouth.
verses.6:13: These, then, are the words which the Lord, the God of Israel, spoke, who led us out of Egypt, out of the great furnace: Because you did not keep my ordinances, but your heart was lifted up, and you were haughty before me, in anger and wrath I delivered you to the furnace in Babylon.
verses.6:14: What shall we do, and how shall we send this report to Jeremiah in Babylon?
verses.6:15: And while Baruch was still praying, behold an angel of the Lord came and said all these words to Baruch: Agent of the light, do not be anxious about how you will send to Jeremiah; for an eagle is coming to you at the hour of light tomorrow, and you will direct him to Jeremiah.
verses.6:16: Therefore, write in a letter: Say to the children of Israel: Let the stranger who comes among you be set apart and let 15 days go by; and after this I will lead you into your city, says the Lord.
verses.6:17: He who is not separated from Babylon will not enter into the city; and I will punish them by keeping them from being received back by the Babylonians, says the Lord.
verses.6:18: And when the angel had said this, he departed from Baruch.
verses.6:19: And Baruch sent to the market of the gentiles and got papyrus and ink and wrote a letter as follows: Baruch, the servant of God, writes to Jeremiah in the captivity of Babylon:
verses.6:20: Greetings! Rejoice, for God has not allowed us to depart from this body grieving for the city which was laid waste and outraged.
verses.6:21: Wherefore the Lord has had compassion on our tears, and has remembered the covenant which he established with our fathers Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
verses.6:22: And he sent his angel to me, and he told me these words which I send to you.
verses.6:24: If, therefore, says the Lord, you listen to my voice, from the mouth of Jeremiah my servant, I will bring the one who listens up from Babylon; but the one who does not listen will become a stranger to Jerusalem and to Babylon.
verses.6:25: And you will test them by means of the water of the Jordan; whoever does not listen will be exposed -- this is the sign of the great seal.
verses.7:1: And Baruch got up and departed from the tomb and found the eagle sitting outside the tomb.
verses.7:2: And the eagle said to him in a human voice: Hail, Baruch, steward of the faith.
verses.7:3: And Baruch said to him: You who speak are chosen from among all the birds of heaven, for this is clear from the gleam of your eyes; tell me, then, what are you doing here?
verses.7:4: And the eagle said to him: I was sent here so that you might through me send whatever message you want.
verses.7:5: And Baruch said to him: Can you carry this message to Jeremiah in Babylon?
verses.7:6: And the eagle said to him: Indeed, it was for this reason I was sent.
verses.7:7: And Baruch took the letter, and 15 figs from Abimelech's basket, and tied them to the eagle's neck and said to him: I say to you, king of the birds, go in peace with good health and carry the message for me.
verses.7:8: Do not be like the raven which Noah sent out and which never came back to him in the ark; but be like the dove which, the third time, brought a report to the righteous one.
verses.7:9: So you also, take this good message to Jeremiah and to those in bondage with him, that it may be well with you-take this papyrus to the people and to the chosen one of God.
verses.7:10: Even if all the birds of heaven surround you and want to fight with you, struggle -- the Lord will give you strength.
verses.7:11: And do not turn aside to the right or to the left, but straight as a speeding arrow, go in the power of God, and the glory of the Lord will be with you the entire way.
verses.7:12: Then the eagle took flight and went away to Babylon, having the letter tied to his neck; and when he arrived he rested on a post outside the city in a desert place.
verses.7:13: And he kept silent until Jeremiah came along, for he and some of the people were coming out to bury a corpse outside the city.
verses.7:14: (For Jeremiah had petitioned king Nebuchadnezzar, saying: "Give me a place where I may bury those of my people who have died;" and the king gave it to him.)
verses.7:15: And as they were coming out with the body, and weeping, they came to where the eagle was.
verses.7:16: And the eagle cried out in a loud voice, saying: I say to you, Jeremiah the chosen one of God, go and gather together the people and come here so that they may hear a letter which I have brought to you from Baruch and Abimelech.
verses.7:17: And when Jeremiah heard this, he glorified God; and he went and gathered together the people along with their wives and children, and he came to where the eagle was.
verses.7:18: And the eagle came down on the corpse, and it revived.
verses.7:19: (Now this took place so that they might believe.)
verses.7:20: And all the people were astounded at what had happened, and said: This is the God who appeared to our fathers in the wilderness through Moses, and now he has appeared to us through the eagle.
verses.7:21: And the eagle said: I say to you, Jeremiah, come, untie this letter and read it to the people -- So he untied the letter and read it to the people.
verses.7:22: And when the people heard it, they wept and put dust on their heads, and they said to Jeremiah: Deliver us and tell us what to do that we may once again enter our city.
verses.7:23: And Jeremiah answered and said to them: Do whatever you heard from the letter, and the Lord will lead us into our city.
verses.7:24: And Jeremiah wrote a letter to Baruch, saying thus: My beloved son, do not be negligent in your prayers, beseeching God on our behalf, that he might direct our way until we come out of the jurisdiction of this lawless king.
verses.7:25: For you have been found righteous before God, and he did not let you come here, lest you see the affliction which has come upon the people at the hands of the Babylonians.
verses.7:26: For it is like a father with an only son, who is given over for punishment; and those who see his father and console him cover his face, lest he see how his son is being punished, and be even more ravaged by grief.
verses.7:27: For thus God took pity on you and did not let you enter Babylon lest you see the affliction of the people.
verses.7:28: For since we came here, grief has not left us, for 66 years today.
verses.7:29: For many times when I went out I found some of the people hung up by king Nebuchadnezzar, crying and saying: "Have mercy on us, God-ZAR!"
verses.7:30: When I heard this, I grieved and cried with two-fold mourning, not only because they were hung up, but because they were calling on a foreign God, saying "Have mercy on us."
verses.7:31: But I remembered days of festivity which we celebrated in Jerusalem before our captivity; and when I remembered, I groaned, and returned to my house wailing and weeping.
verses.7:32: Now, then, pray in the place where you are -- you and Abimelech -- for this people, that they may listen to my voice and to the decrees of my mouth, so that we may depart from here.
verses.7:33: For I tell you that the entire time that we have spent here they have kept us in subjection, saying: Recite for us a song from the songs of Zion -- the song of your God.
verses.7:34: And we reply to them: How shall we sing for you since we are in a foreign land?
verses.7:35: And after this, Jeremiah tied the letter to the eagle's neck, saying: Go in peace, and may the Lord watch over both of us.
verses.7:36: And the eagle took flight and came to Jerusalem and gave the letter to Baruch; and when he had untied it he read it and kissed it and wept when he heard about the distresses and afflictions of the people.
verses.7:37: But Jeremiah took the figs and distributed them to the sick among the people, and he kept teaching them to abstain from the pollutions of the gentiles of Babylon. 6
verses.8:1: And the day came in which the Lord brought the people out of Babylon.
verses.8:2: And the Lord said to Jeremiah: Rise up -- you and the people -- and come to the Jordan and say to the people: Let anyone who desires the Lord forsake the works of Babylon.
verses.8:3: As for the men who took wives from them and the women who took husbands from them -- those who listen to you shall cross over, and you take them into Jerusalem; but those who do not listen to you, do not lead them there.
verses.8:4: And Jeremiah spoke these words to the people, and they arose and came to the Jordan to cross over.
verses.8:5: As he told them the words that the Lord had spoken to him, half of those who had taken spouses from them did not wish to listen to Jeremiah, but said to him: We will never forsake our wives, but we will bring them back with us into our city.
verses.8:6: So they crossed the Jordan and came to Jerusalem.
verses.8:7: And Jeremiah and Baruch and Abimelech stood up and said: No man joined with Babylonians shall enter this city!
verses.8:8: And they said to one another: Let us arise and return to Babylon to our place -- And they departed.
verses.8:9: But while they were coming to Babylon, the Babylonians came out to meet them, saying: You shall not enter our city, for you hated us and you left us secretly; therefore you cannot come in with us.
verses.8:10: For we have taken a solemn oath together in the name of our god to receive neither you nor your children, since you left us secretly.
verses.8:11: And when they heard this, they returned and came to a desert place some distance from Jerusalem and built a city for themselves and named it 'SAMARIA.'
verses.8:12: And Jeremiah sent to them, saying: Repent, for the angel of righteousness is coming and will lead you to your exalted place.
verses.9:1: Now those who were with Jeremiah were rejoicing and offering sacrifices on behalf of the people for nine days.
verses.9:2: But on the tenth, Jeremiah alone offered sacrifice.
verses.9:3: And he prayed a prayer, saying: Holy, holy, holy, fragrant aroma of the living trees, true light that enlightens me until I ascend to you;
verses.9:4: For your mercy, I beg you -- for the sweet voice of the two seraphim, I beg -- for another fragrant aroma.
verses.9:5: And may Michael, archangel of righteousness, who opens the gates to the righteous, be my guardian (?) until he causes the righteous to enter.
verses.9:6: I beg you, almighty Lord of all creation, unbegotten and incomprehensible, in whom all judgment was hidden before these things came into existence.
verses.9:7: When Jeremiah had said this, and while he was standing in the altar-area with Baruch and Abimelech, he became as one whose soul had departed.
verses.9:8: And Baruch and Abimelech were weeping and crying out in a loud voice: Woe to us! For our father Jeremiah has left us -- the priest of God has departed!
verses.9:9: And all the people heard their weeping and they all ran to them and saw Jeremiah lying on the ground as if dead.
verses.9:10: And they tore their garments and put dust on their heads and wept bitterly.
verses.9:11: And after this they prepared to bury him.
verses.9:12: And behold, there came a voice saying: Do not bury the one who yet lives, for his soul is returning to his body!
verses.9:13: And when they heard the voice they did not bury him, but stayed around his tabernacle for three days saying, "when will he arise?"
verses.9:14: And after three days his soul came back into his body and he raised his voice in the midst of them all and said: Glorify God with one voice! All of you glorify God and the son of God who awakens us -- messiah Jesus -- the light of all the ages, the inextinguishable lamp, the life of faith.
verses.9:15: But after these times there shall be 477 years more and he comes to earth.
verses.9:16: And the tree of life planted in the midst of paradise will cause all the unfruitful trees to bear fruit, and will grow and sprout forth.
verses.9:17: And the trees that had sprouted and became haughty and said: "We have supplied our power (?) to the air," he will cause them to wither, with the grandeur of their branches, and he will cause them to be judged -- that firmly rooted tree!
verses.9:18: And what is crimson will become white as wool -- the snow will be blackened -- the sweet waters will become salty, and the salty sweet, in the intense light of the joy of God.
verses.9:19: And he will bless the isles so that they become fruitful by the word of the mouth of his messiah.
verses.9:20: For he shall come, and he will go out and choose for himself twelve apostles to proclaim the news among the nations-- he whom I have seen adorned by his father and coming into the world on the Mount of Olives -- and he shall fill the hungry souls.
verses.9:21: When Jeremiah was saying this concerning the son of God -- that he is coming into the world -- the people became very angry and said: This is a repetition of the words spoken by Isaiah son of Amos, when he said: I saw God and the son of God.
verses.9:22: Come, then, and let us not kill him by the same sort of death with which we killed Isaiah, but let us stone him with stones.
verses.9:23: And Baruch and Abimelech were greatly grieved because they wanted to hear in full the mysteries that he had seen.
verses.9:24: But Jeremiah said to them: Be silent and weep not, for they cannot kill me until I describe for you everything I saw.
verses.9:25: And he said to them: Bring a stone here to me.
verses.9:26: And he set it up and said: Light of the ages, make this stone to become like me in appearance, until I have described to Baruch and Abimelech everything I saw.
verses.9:27: Then the stone, by God's command, took on the appearance of Jeremiah.
verses.9:28: And they were stoning the stone, supposing that it was Jeremiah!
verses.9:29: But Jeremiah delivered to Baruch and to Abimelech all the mysteries he had seen, and forthwith he stood in the midst of the people desiring to complete his ministry.
verses.9:30: Then the stone cried out, saying: O foolish children of Israel, why do you stone me, supposing that I am Jeremiah? Behold, Jeremiah is standing in your midst!
verses.9:31: And when they saw him, immediately they rushed upon him with many stones, and his ministry was fulfilled.
verses.9:32: And when Baruch and Abimelech came, they buried him, and taking the stone they placed it on his tomb and inscribed it thus: This is the stone that was the ally of Jeremiah.

verses.1:1: There dwelt a man in Babylon, called Joacim:
verses.1:2: And he took a wife, whose name was Susanna, the daughter of Chelcias, a very fair woman, and one that feared the Lord.
verses.1:3: Her parents also were righteous, and taught their daughter according to the law of Moses.
verses.1:4: Now Joacim was a great rich man, and had a fair garden joining unto his house: and to him resorted the Jews; because he was more honourable than all others.
verses.1:5: The same year were appointed two of the ancients of the people to be judges, such as the Lord spake of, that wickedness came from Babylon from ancient judges, who seemed to govern the people.
verses.1:6: These kept much at Joacim’s house: and all that had any suits in law came unto them.
verses.1:7: Now when the people departed away at noon, Susanna went into her husband’s garden to walk.
verses.1:8: And the two elders saw her going in every day, and walking; so that their lust was inflamed toward her.
verses.1:9: And they perverted their own mind, and turned away their eyes, that they might not look unto heaven, nor remember just judgments.
verses.1:10: And albeit they both were wounded with her love, yet durst not one shew another his grief.
verses.1:11: For they were ashamed to declare their lust, that they desired to have to do with her.
verses.1:12: Yet they watched diligently from day to day to see her.
verses.1:13: And the one said to the other, Let us now go home: for it is dinner time.
verses.1:14: So when they were gone out, they parted the one from the other, and turning back again they came to the same place; and after that they had asked one another the cause, they acknowledged their lust: then appointed they a time both together, when they might find her alone.
verses.1:15: And it fell out, as they watched a fit time, she went in as before with two maids only, and she was desirous to wash herself in the garden: for it was hot.
verses.1:16: And there was no body there save the two elders, that had hid themselves, and watched her.
verses.1:17: Then she said to her maids, Bring me oil and washing balls, and shut the garden doors, that I may wash me.
verses.1:18: And they did as she bade them, and shut the garden doors, and went out themselves at privy doors to fetch the things that she had commanded them: but they saw not the elders, because they were hid.
verses.1:19: Now when the maids were gone forth, the two elders rose up, and ran unto her, saying,
verses.1:20: Behold, the garden doors are shut, that no man can see us, and we are in love with thee; therefore consent unto us, and lie with us.
verses.1:21: If thou wilt not, we will bear witness against thee, that a young man was with thee: and therefore thou didst send away thy maids from thee.
verses.1:22: Then Susanna sighed, and said, I am straitened on every side: for if I do this thing, it is death unto me: and if I do it not I cannot escape your hands.
verses.1:23: It is better for me to fall into your hands, and not do it, than to sin in the sight of the Lord.
verses.1:24: With that Susanna cried with a loud voice: and the two elders cried out against her.
verses.1:25: Then ran the one, and opened the garden door.
verses.1:26: So when the servants of the house heard the cry in the garden, they rushed in at the privy door, to see what was done unto her.
verses.1:27: But when the elders had declared their matter, the servants were greatly ashamed: for there was never such a report made of Susanna.
verses.1:28: And it came to pass the next day, when the people were assembled to her husband Joacim, the two elders came also full of mischievous imagination against Susanna to put her to death;
verses.1:29: And said before the people, Send for Susanna, the daughter of Chelcias, Joacim’s wife. And so they sent.
verses.1:30: So she came with her father and mother, her children, and all her kindred.
verses.1:31: Now Susanna was a very delicate woman, and beauteous to behold.
verses.1:32: And these wicked men commanded to uncover her face, (for she was covered) that they might be filled with her beauty.
verses.1:33: Therefore her friends and all that saw her wept.
verses.1:34: Then the two elders stood up in the midst of the people, and laid their hands upon her head.
verses.1:35: And she weeping looked up toward heaven: for her heart trusted in the Lord.
verses.1:36: And the elders said, As we walked in the garden alone, this woman came in with two maids, and shut the garden doors, and sent the maids away.
verses.1:37: Then a young man, who there was hid, came unto her, and lay with her.
verses.1:38: Then we that stood in a corner of the garden, seeing this wickedness, ran unto them.
verses.1:39: And when we saw them together, the man we could not hold: for he was stronger than we, and opened the door, and leaped out.
verses.1:40: But having taken this woman, we asked who the young man was, but she would not tell us: these things do we testify.
verses.1:41: Then the assembly believed them as those that were the elders and judges of the people: so they condemned her to death.
verses.1:42: Then Susanna cried out with a loud voice, and said, O everlasting God, that knowest the secrets, and knowest all things before they be:
verses.1:43: Thou knowest that they have borne false witness against me, and, behold, I must die; whereas I never did such things as these men have maliciously invented against me.
verses.1:44: And the Lord heard her voice.
verses.1:45: Therefore when she was led to be put to death, the Lord raised up the holy spirit of a young youth whose name was Daniel:
verses.1:46: Who cried with a loud voice, I am clear from the blood of this woman.
verses.1:47: Then all the people turned them toward him, and said, What mean these words that thou hast spoken?
verses.1:48: So he standing in the midst of them said, Are ye such fools, ye sons of Israel, that without examination or knowledge of the truth ye have condemned a daughter of Israel?
verses.1:49: Return again to the place of judgment: for they have borne false witness against her.
verses.1:50: Wherefore all the people turned again in haste, and the elders said unto him, Come, sit down among us, and shew it us, seeing God hath given thee the honour of an elder.
verses.1:51: Then said Daniel unto them, Put these two aside one far from another, and I will examine them.
verses.1:52: So when they were put asunder one from another, he called one of them, and said unto him, O thou that art waxen old in wickedness, now thy sins which thou hast committed aforetime are come to light.
verses.1:53: For thou hast pronounced false judgment and hast condemned the innocent and hast let the guilty go free; albeit the Lord saith, The innocent and righteous shalt thou not slay.
verses.1:54: Now then, if thou hast seen her, tell me, Under what tree sawest thou them companying together? Who answered, Under a mastick tree.
verses.1:55: And Daniel said, Very well; thou hast lied against thine own head; for even now the angel of God hath received the sentence of God to cut thee in two.
verses.1:56: So he put him aside, and commanded to bring the other, and said unto him, O thou seed of Chanaan, and not of Juda, beauty hath deceived thee, and lust hath perverted thine heart.
verses.1:57: Thus have ye dealt with the daughters of Israel, and they for fear companied with you: but the daughter of Juda would not abide your wickedness.
verses.1:58: Now therefore tell me, Under what tree didst thou take them companying together? Who answered, Under an holm tree.
verses.1:59: Then said Daniel unto him, Well; thou hast also lied against thine own head: for the angel of God waiteth with the sword to cut thee in two, that he may destroy you.
verses.1:60: With that all the assembly cried out with a loud voice, and praised God, who saveth them that trust in him.
verses.1:61: And they arose against the two elders, for Daniel had convicted them of false witness by their own mouth:
verses.1:62: And according to the law of Moses they did unto them in such sort as they maliciously intended to do to their neighbour: and they put them to death. Thus the innocent blood was saved the same day.
verses.1:63: Therefore Chelcias and his wife praised God for their daughter Susanna, with Joacim her husband, and all the kindred, because there was no dishonesty found in her.
verses.1:64: From that day forth was Daniel had in great reputation in the sight of the people.

verses.1:1: And king Astyages was gathered to his fathers, and Cyrus of Persia received his kingdom.
verses.1:2: And Daniel conversed with the king, and was honoured above all his friends.
verses.1:3: Now the Babylons had an idol, called Bel, and there were spent upon him every day twelve great measures of fine flour, and forty sheep, and six vessels of wine.
verses.1:4: And the king worshipped it and went daily to adore it: but Daniel worshipped his own God. And the king said unto him, Why dost not thou worship Bel?
verses.1:5: Who answered and said, Because I may not worship idols made with hands, but the living God, who hath created the heaven and the earth, and hath sovereignty over all flesh.
verses.1:6: Then said the king unto him, Thinkest thou not that Bel is a living God? seest thou not how much he eateth and drinketh every day?
verses.1:7: Then Daniel smiled, and said, O king, be not deceived: for this is but clay within, and brass without, and did never eat or drink any thing.
verses.1:8: So the king was wroth, and called for his priests, and said unto them, If ye tell me not who this is that devoureth these expences, ye shall die.
verses.1:9: But if ye can certify me that Bel devoureth them, then Daniel shall die: for he hath spoken blasphemy against Bel. And Daniel said unto the king, Let it be according to thy word.
verses.1:10: Now the priests of Bel were threescore and ten, beside their wives and children. And the king went with Daniel into the temple of Bel.
verses.1:11: So Bel’s priests said, Lo, we go out: but thou, O king, set on the meat, and make ready the wine, and shut the door fast and seal it with thine own signet;
verses.1:12: And to morrow when thou comest in, if thou findest not that Bel hath eaten up all, we will suffer death: or else Daniel, that speaketh falsely against us.
verses.1:13: And they little regarded it: for under the table they had made a privy entrance, whereby they entered in continually, and consumed those things.
verses.1:14: So when they were gone forth, the king set meats before Bel. Now Daniel had commanded his servants to bring ashes, and those they strewed throughout all the temple in the presence of the king alone: then went they out, and shut the door, and sealed it with the king’s signet, and so departed.
verses.1:15: Now in the night came the priests with their wives and children, as they were wont to do, and did eat and drink up all.
verses.1:16: In the morning betime the king arose, and Daniel with him.
verses.1:17: And the king said, Daniel, are the seals whole? And he said, Yea, O king, they be whole.
verses.1:18: And as soon as he had opened the dour, the king looked upon the table, and cried with a loud voice, Great art thou, O Bel, and with thee is no deceit at all.
verses.1:19: Then laughed Daniel, and held the king that he should not go in, and said, Behold now the pavement, and mark well whose footsteps are these.
verses.1:20: And the king said, I see the footsteps of men, women, and children. And then the king was angry,
verses.1:21: And took the priests with their wives and children, who shewed him the privy doors, where they came in, and consumed such things as were upon the table.
verses.1:22: Therefore the king slew them, and delivered Bel into Daniel’s power, who destroyed him and his temple.
verses.1:23: And in that same place there was a great dragon, which they of Babylon worshipped.
verses.1:24: And the king said unto Daniel, Wilt thou also say that this is of brass? lo, he liveth, he eateth and drinketh; thou canst not say that he is no living god: therefore worship him.
verses.1:25: Then said Daniel unto the king, I will worship the Lord my God: for he is the living God.
verses.1:26: But give me leave, O king, and I shall slay this dragon without sword or staff. The king said, I give thee leave.
verses.1:27: Then Daniel took pitch, and fat, and hair, and did seethe them together, and made lumps thereof: this he put in the dragon’s mouth, and so the dragon burst in sunder : and Daniel said, Lo, these are the gods ye worship.
verses.1:28: When they of Babylon heard that, they took great indignation, and conspired against the king, saying, The king is become a Jew, and he hath destroyed Bel, he hath slain the dragon, and put the priests to death.
verses.1:29: So they came to the king, and said, Deliver us Daniel, or else we will destroy thee and thine house.
verses.1:30: Now when the king saw that they pressed him sore, being constrained, he delivered Daniel unto them:
verses.1:31: Who cast him into the lions’ den: where he was six days.
verses.1:32: And in the den there were seven lions, and they had given them every day two carcases, and two sheep: which then were not given to them, to the intent they might devour Daniel.
verses.1:33: Now there was in Jewry a prophet, called Habbacuc, who had made pottage, and had broken bread in a bowl, and was going into the field, for to bring it to the reapers.
verses.1:34: But the angel of the Lord said unto Habbacuc, Go, carry the dinner that thou hast into Babylon unto Daniel, who is in the lions’ den.
verses.1:35: And Habbacuc said, Lord, I never saw Babylon; neither do I know where the den is.
verses.1:36: Then the angel of the Lord took him by the crown, and bare him by the hair of his head, and through the vehemency of his spirit set him in Babylon over the den.
verses.1:37: And Habbacuc cried, saying, O Daniel, Daniel, take the dinner which God hath sent thee.
verses.1:38: And Daniel said, Thou hast remembered me, O God: neither hast thou forsaken them that seek thee and love thee.
verses.1:39: So Daniel arose, and did eat: and the angel of the Lord set Habbacuc in his own place again immediately.
